name: The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari, with Live Piano (Free Holloween event @ SFPL)
description:
This Halloween, come hear acclaimed pianist Frederick Hodges accompany SFPL’s screening of the classic silent horror film, The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari. Famous for its Expressionist sets, its bizarre plot twists, and its paranoid psychological atmosphere, Caligari presents an unsettling story about a mysterious hypnotist, his patient, and a series of violent murders.
Don't miss this exciting evening of film and live music!
https://sfpl.org/index.php?pg=1033634001

name: Crypto Happy Hour and Comedy Mixer
description:
TICKET LINK:
https://bit.ly/2MA57Db

6pm - Networking / meet and greet
7pm - Comedy show
8:30pm - Drinks after the show with the comedians and presenter

The Crypto Happy Hour and Comedy Mixer is the coolest Blockchain related event in San Francisco. Just walking distance from Bart - our venue PianoFight is not just a theater, it’s also a highly rated restaurant and bar. Wherther you're a Cypto pro, or simply looking for a hip-fun night out in the City, this event is right for you.

Sponsors:
San Francisco Blockchain Collective
The SF Blockchain Collective is dedicated to Crypto and Blockchain Education.

Comedy Couch SF
Comedy Couch SF is committed to producing diverse, innovative comedy based events.

Comedians:
Kip Fuller
Rose Hindes
Trish Pandya
James Mwara

PianoFight’s not just a theater, it’s also a restaurant and bar!
★★★★½ on Yelp
★★★★½ on Google
★★★★★ on Facebook

“Reasonably priced New American bites and cocktails in an unpretentious setting” - Zagat

“The best party spot in the neighborhood” - The Bay Bridged

“A hot SF scene” - SF Chronicle

If you plan on dining, we recommend you arrive 1.5 hours early so you have plenty of time to eat before the show. Restaurant seating is first come first serve. Drinks are always allowed in the theaters.

PARKING
Street parking is free after 6pm. We’re located 2 blocks from Powell BART, numerous muni lines and there are 3 parking lots within 1 block.

TICKET SALES AND RSVP
The SFBC does not accept payment from direct ticket sales, however our partners, vendors and promoters and their partners may charge a fee.

name: Crypto Happy Hour & Comedy Night
description:
Welcome to SF's first Crypto Happy Hour and Comedy night. Whether you're a Crypto pro, or just want dinner and comedy - we encourage you to come and mix, mingle and laugh with us at this fun and informative event!

TIMELINES

6 pm until 7 pm

Crypto Happy Hour - mix & mingle

7 pm until 10 pm

Comedy Incubator (includes intermission)

Comedy Couch SF

Comedy Couch SF is a volunteer run organization that was founded by NY Transplant Rose Hienz and SF Native and Kip Fuller in May 2017. Today, Rose and Kip are widely known for producing some of SF's funniest, hippest and most diverse participatory Comedy Incubators and stand up comedy shows. Comedians Daniele Midi-Mindix, Rose Hienz and Kip Fuller will host the Happy Hour as well as the Comedy Incubator show.

SF Blockchain collective

Co-host Gee Sivalingam is the founder of SF Blockchain collective, which provides Crytpo Currency education. Gee is a fun guy and once tried stand up comedy in a past life.

Serendipia

Co-host Jean Loick Michaux is the co-founder of the Crypto based Serendipia community mentioned here in the San Francisco Chronicle. His community is very cool, and fosters a culture that supports Crytpo based creators and visionaries.

CHECK IN INSTRUCTIONS:

The Mixer begins at 6 PM but check-in time for the Comedy show begins at 7 pm. The Comedy room located towards the rear of the restaurant. To claim your seat enter the comedy room and walk to the front of the performance area and a host will ask your name and route you to a seat.

FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS:

CAN I MAKE A DONATION USING CRYPTO or CASH?

Yes - we will accept Crypto and cash donations at each event!

IS THERE FOOD AND A FULL BAR?
Yes

IS THERE AN AGE REQUIREMENT?

The Comedy show is 18+ only.

IS THERE A DRINK MINIMUM?

No drink minimum

IS THERE PARKING AVAILABLE

There are many parking spaces nearby.

FURTHER QUESTIONS:

Email is at: [masked]

BioPacific Toastmasters (http://biopacific.toastmastersclubs.org) can help elevate your thinking (with "brain lifting") as well as improve your leadership and communication skills as follows:
- Scientists can break the ice and enrich presentations by researching their topic and organizing their speech with visual aids that inspire their audience
- Entrepreneurs can practice getting to the point or telling stories when pitching how their technology transforms industries
- Business professionals can enhance the impact of their talks by persuading audiences with power through word choice, rhetorical devices, vocal variety, and body language

Let's overcome America's #1 fear of public speaking together while talking about various topics, networking, and having fun!

name: SF Storytellers Weekly Meeting
description:
Want to keep your audience riveted at a work meeting, a wedding toast, a presentation, and anything in between? Join SF Storytellers, the only Toastmasters club in San Francisco focused on STORYTELLING! Learn helpful story tips and get feedback from everyone at the club. Come one, come all!

This meeting will take place on the first floor of 1680 Mission St. When you enter, sign in at the front desk. When the security guard lets you in, take a left and then a right. Go past 3 doors. The conference room is the 4th door on the left. If you reach the printer, you've gone too far. Look for our Toastmasters banner!

The meetings take place at the Segment office (100 California) - Floor 7. Guests need to tell the lobby attendant that they are going to Toastmasters in order to be let in. Guests should also sign in at the Segment front desk once they are on the 7th floor. The room we meet in is right next to the front desk.

name: Early Risers Toastmasters Meeting
description:
Early Risers Toastmasters is a community club open to anyone who is interested in joining. We are a friendly and diverse group of people who support each other in improving our communications and leadership skills. We receive an exceptional number of awards due to the strength of our education program.

Early Risers Toastmasters, established in 1958, is one of the oldest Toastmasters clubs in the Bay Area. Over the years Early Risers has witnessed the bloom of Silicon Valley and helped club members take an active role in the building of one of the most amazing cultures in our nation, if not the world.

We start each Tuesday morning with a fun and inspirational meeting, which ends in time for everyone to go about all their other activities for the day. Our members rarely have conflicts with our early morning meeting time, so they are able to attend regularly and develop new skills quickly.

If you are interested in finding out about us, feel free to drop as a guest any Tuesday morning. After attending a meeting, or two or three meetings if you’d like, if you decide to join the club we'll assign you a mentor, put you on the speaking schedule, and you'll be on your way to becoming an effective communicator and leader.

Better news for college and university students, 50% off of Early Risers Club dues.

Our Club Contacts:
* Stephanie Charles, DTM (President):[masked]

* KC Huang, DTM (Vice President Education):[masked]

* John McGowan, ACG,CL (Vice President Public Relations):[masked]

• Important to know

name: Golden Gate Toastmasters Weekly Meeting
description:
For 80 years, Golden Gate Toastmasters has provided its members with weekly public speaking opportunities, a supportive environment, and a venue for developing new friendships. We're a club devoted to improving each others public speaking and leadership potential. Individually we each bring unique experiences and perspectives to the group, and collectively we help each other achieve many personal and professional goals.
We are here to speak, to have fun, and to help all individuals to succeed.
Any and all guests are welcome. Our meetings are typically about 20-40 people. Check out our website for more information: http://www.goldengatetoastmasters.com/

name: Promasters Club Meeting
description:
WHO: We are a group of about 35 men and women meeting weekly since 1999 to improve each other's speaking and leadership potential in a supportive, fun, and friendly environment. We range in age from early 20's to 70+, we come from many parts of the world (some are quite exotic), and we bring unique experiences and perspectives to the group. We help each other to achieve many personal and professional goals.

Our club has received the President's Distinguished Club award 7 years in a row. How do we earn it and why do we bother? It is a recognition from Toastmasters International awarded to clubs that provide the highest quality club experience to their members, both on the educational and on the leadership track. It takes careful planning, careful tracking, and the help of every member.

WHEN: Every Thursday from 7:30 am - 8:30am. Early meetings are the best! We start & finish on-time and we get plenty of positive energy for the last two days of the work week.

WHERE: The best part of our club - there is an amazing breakfast involved!

name: Spanish Bilingual SF Toastmasters Weekly Meeting
description:
Join us every Thursday for this unique Toastmasters meeting in two languages! Every meeting is two meetings in one: an English segment, followed by a Spanish segment. Each segment is approximately 30-45 minutes, or 90 minutes total, adjourning promptly at 8:00pm.

Each segment includes:
* 1-2 prepared speeches (5-7 minutes)
* Formal speech evaluations (2-3 minutes)
* Impromptu speaking opportunities (Table Topics, 2-3 minutes)
* Reports: Grammarian, Ah Counter, Timer (1-3 minutes)
* After meetings, many of us go to a nearby restaurant for food and drinks.

Learn more and request a visit at https://www.clubbilinguesf.org/visit

LOCATION: Wells Fargo, 420 Montgomery Street, 3rd Floor, San Francisco, CA

name: Club Consultants & Club Coaches Webinar
description:
Have you experienced everything that Toastmasters has to offer? Club coaching & consulting offers one of the most rewarding experiences in Toastmasters - helping a struggling club to become whole again, and become a Distinguished Club.

Join us for a Growth Team webinar. It will be two 30-minute modules, about Club Consultant and Club Coach programs.

Pre TestBash Meetup
description:
TestBash, Ministry of Testings software testing conference, is coming West. There's an exciting range of topics and a wonderful list of speakers that you will no doubt learn tons from. https://ministryoftesting.com/events/testbash-san-francisco-2018

There's always social events around each TestBash too, a chance to get to socialize with the attendees and speakers. You can attend these even if you don't have a ticket to the conference. Please do RSVP here, to give an idea of numbers.

Thanks to our very kind sponsors at Credit Karma, nibbles and drinks will be included so you get socializing and dinner all at once! You can follow them on Twitter and tweet your thanks https://twitter.com/creditkarma and find out more information about them on their website https://www.creditkarma.com/

name: Post TestBash Meetup
description:
After two days of attending TestBash San Francisco talks, your mind is buzzing with all the questions you forgot to ask. Or potential conversations you'd like to have with other attendees. A reminder of what those talks will be: https://ministryoftesting.com/events/testbash-san-francisco-2018.

Maybe you're in the area but not attending the conference, you can pop along and chat to the speakers, other attendees and community members at the Post TestBash San Francisco social. This is a fantastic opportunity to take advantage of the community traveling to San Francisco for this event.

Please RSVP here so we have an idea of numbers to expect.

This meetup is not sponsored so please remember to bring your dollars with you.

name: Knative: Going Serverless with Kubernetes
description:
Zoom: https://zoom.us/j/432512885

We will be introducing Knative, Kubernetes-based platform to build, deploy, and manage modern serverless workloads and it is supported by Google, Pivotal, IBM and Red Hat. This will be a breakdown of its components, features, future and its application.

name: Autonomous Performance and Security for Hybrid Clouds
description:
-------------
Slack: https://devopsonline.herokuapp.com
Networking : 6 - 6:30pm
Presentation: 6:30 - 8:30pm
------------

Hands on workshop: Autonomous Performance and Security for Hybrid Clouds

Details: Today’s applications and systems are inherently complex. Solving an application issue in production can be a daunting task. In addition, unified security monitoring and auditing is critical to detecting modern threats that are rapidly evolving to exploit the growing visibility gaps.

Come to this hands-on lab to see how Oracle Management Cloud’s unified platform leverages machine learning and advanced analytics to rapidly identify the root cause of application issues, detects advanced threats and ensures secure configurations in hybrid cloud environments.

Speaker: Vijay Tatkar | Director, Oracle Management Cloud

Intro: Vijay is a Director of Product Management for Oracle Management Cloud. Vijay has over 29 years of industry experience, about 25+ years of those managing developers and development tools engineering. He has worked in, and managed, Developer Tools, Analyzers and Cloud computing tools in the past. Rapid changes in developer trends to DevOps, Microservices driven architectures and Cloud and making sense of the enormous amount of data generated has drawn Vijay to Oracle Systems & Security Management Cloud (OMC) In his time outside work, Vijay enjoys hiking the wonderful California landscape, music and is an avid fan of Cricket.

Speaker: Dave Le Roy | Director of Product Management at Oracle Corporation

Intro: Dave Le Roy is a Director of Product Management for Oracle Management Cloud and Oracle Enterprise Manager. He has been in the Systems and Cloud Management Products group for over 15 years. Current responsibilities include driving Outbound Product Management & Business Development. Dave also manages Regional Sales Support in North America and Latin America.

name: SF October Meetup: Special announcement
description:
THIS WILL BE THE LAST SAN FRANCISCO MEETUP HOSTED BY US.

We have a special announcement to make that explains why we've been absent recently. This will be the last meetup we're hosting.

Let this breakfast be the opportunity to exchange news and help each other.

Feel free to come every other Wednesday, we will be thrilled to see you.

name: BotsNBeer - ARM TECH CON
description:
This months Bots n Beer event is being held at the San Jose Convention Center in conjunction with Arm TechCon. If you wish to attend Arm TechCon, please use code 18ARMBB for $300 off a full conference pass. Register here. https://www.armtechcon.com/registration.html

Speakers:

Meet NXP’s Drone expert Iain Galloway and learn about the HoverGames Drone kit and the integration of IoT and UAV!

NXP’s HoverGames drone FMU reference design runs DroneCode.org PX4.io flight software stack and SDK. It can be used as a system controller for other small autonomous vehicles. NXP has prepared an adapter board to enable mobile IOT by attaching the Rapid IOT prototyping kit.
The Rapid IoT prototyping kit integrates 20 devices into one package with a web based drag and drop IDE to drastically reduce development time and effort. Hundreds of external sensor, actuator and communications Click modules work with this system.

Hear from Arm Innovators Will Roscoe (Co-Founder, Donkey Car) and Kwabena Aygeman (Co-Founder, OpenMV) explaining two ways to use an Open MV cam to drive a Donkey Car.

name: Bots & BBQ - Circuit Launch Oakland
description:
Celebrate the end of the month with Circuit Launch, Caipirinhas and Brazilian BBQ!

Circuit Launch is THE place to build robots, whether you need a hot desk or an office, production floor space or access to the equipment and classes in how to print, design and produce almost anything!

Show off your robot or robotics-related project cause demos are awesome. Looking to hire or be hired in a robotics-related company? Have something to offer to robotics startups? We do announcements and introductions.

IF you like this meetup then join Silicon Valley Robotics as a startup or as an individual member! (http://www.svrobo.org/membership/)

What else would you like to see at the Silicon Valley Robotics Bots and Beer SF? Please let us know!

Your organizers,

Andra & Miranda

name: Bots & Beer in Silicon Valley
description:

We're also always interested in new venue hosts - ideally robotics/tech companies with something to show off! (Attendees approx 80 in Silicon Valley and 50 in SF/East Bay)

We love show'n'tell and always have 'open mic' where you can share something about your robot/robot event. Join Silicon Valley Robotics (https://svrobo.org) as a startup or as an individual to stay in the loop for more robotics events, startup competitions, demo days etc.

Also - for most up to date information see the Silicon Valley Robotics meetup and or the Silicon Valley Robotics calendar on svrobo.org

best, Andra

name: BotsNBeer in SF/East Bay
description:
Come hear the latest robotics news - always looking for new venues, hosts, sponsors and co-organizers!

Show off your robot or robotics-related project cause demos are awesome. Looking to hire or be hired in a robotics-related company? Have something to offer to robotics startups? We do announcements and introductions.

And we also have FREE BEER*! But there's a catch of course -- we'd like you to be a Silicon Valley Robotics individual member! But membership is easy: sign up now at http://www.svrobo.org/membership/. (http://www.svrobo.org/membership/)

Your organizer,

Miranda Harries (miranda@svrobo.org)

name: BEER/WINE PONG & 90's PARTY with International Travelers and Locals
description:
NOTE: This event is EVERY FRIDAY!! The date changes on meetup as it gets closer to the event start time because this is a recurring event, but this event happens every Friday at 9PM! Signup is at 9PM - YOU MUST ARRIVE BEFORE 9:30PM TO PLAY IN THE GAMES. ENTRY IS THROUGH SCORE BAR (next door to Horizon). We will be joining the international travelers group - here is the main event link: http://www.meetup.com/SanFranciscoHostel/events/220819213/

They will place you on a team based on your country and your team will rotate around the room & play beer pong, flip cup, and relays against the other teams. ***The point of this event is to meet the others in the room while competing, then finish the night in the dance/club part of the venue.

Come join us, have some drinks, and meet some new people. When you arrive, tell the girl at the door you're with the meet up if you'd like to be teammates with others in the group. RSVP is *required* for planning purposes. Thanks!

Here's the INFO:

We do a weekly tournament on Fridays - we mainly get about 50-60 backpackers who are staying at hostels around the city, along with locals who want to meet new people and share travel stories.

FREE to play! FREE entry before 10PM with a drink special purchase and RSVP!

Drink Special: 6 CUPS of WINE for $12 before 9:30PM, 6 BEERS for $18 before 9:30PM, 6 WELL SPIRITS for $24 before 9:30PM.

Win Prizes!
Games: Beer Pong, Flip Cup, Relays

--> Everyone's placed on a team based on your country (to make it easy to meet people).
--> Teams compete at flip cup, relays, and beer pong.
--> Play -or- just watch, drink cheap beer and be social!

Meet & compete against travelers, locals, au pairs and students!

'Like' us on Facebook *and* RSVP that you're attending & get a $1 shot!
LIKE US HERE: https://www.facebook.com/beerpubcrawl
RSVP HERE: http://www.sfhostelparty.com (http://www.sfhostelparty.com/)

******************************************************
WHEN: EVERY FRIDAY!!
WHERE: HORIZON LOUNGE - 498 Broadway St, near the corner of Kearny St & Broadway
(Signup with the Beer Olympics coordinator)
TIME: Signup at 9PM - Be sure to arrive by 9:30PM to play!

name: Murder Mystery Pub & Grub Crawl. Drink, Dine & Solve Crime! (EVERY SUNDAY)
description:
NOTE: This event is EVERY SUNDAY!! The date changes on meetup as it gets closer to the event start time because this is a recurring event, but this event happens every Sunday at 7:30PM!

We'll be joining international travelers to solve the murder case as we head to 3 restaurant pubs. Win murder mystery clues along the way by competing at rock paper scissors against fellow detectives. Come up with the most creative/funny murder motive and win a prize. Plus $3 beer/wine along the way! NOTE: all drinks/food are CASH ONLY.

********************************************************************

RSVP *required* here: http://www.sfhostelparty.com/

This event is every week.

Meeting point: Score Bar - meet *outside*. You *must* check in between 7:30PM and 7:45PM if you are planning to attend - please do not try and join us mid-way into the crawl.

We stay at each place for about 40 minutes before heading off to the next stop and we eat a different course in each place.

================
Please bring $11.75 in cash for the food, plus $3.25 for tax/tips. This will cover all the food items listed below, as well as dessert. Both the food and tip money will be collected at the beginning of the evening. Drinks can be purchased at each place *individually* and are cash only.

MENU (NO FOOD SUBSTITUTIONS):
Restaurant #1 - Spring salad topped with Garlic Noodles
Restaurant #2 - Margherita Pizza
Restaurant #3 - Chocolate Eclairs & Cream Puffs
================

NOTE: Drinks/food are cash only.

**Please do NOT call Score Bar. We do not eat there and they are not involved with the event. We just meet outside at 7:30pm and then leave at 7:45pm after everyone is checked in***

name: Drinks with International Travelers (EVERY WEDNESDAY)
description:
This pub crawl is EVERY WEDNESDAY!! NOTE: The date changes on meetup as it gets closer to the event start time because this is a recurring event, but this event happens every Wednesday at 9PM!

We will be joining my other group and picking up a groups of backpackers from local hostels - here is the main event link: http://www.meetup.com/San-Francisco-things-to-do/events/82926222/

Hi everyone - There's a pub crawl run by volunteers at hostels in SF so that there's a place for backpackers and locals to meet each other. The event gets a bunch of travelers from all over the city along with locals. Come join us, have some drinks, and meet some new peeps. When you arrive, tell the girl at the door you're with the meet up so that everyone can find each other. RSVP is required for planning purposes. Thanks!

Here's the INFO:

We do a weekly rock-paper-scissors tournament pub crawl on Wednesdays. Everyone competes while moving from bar-to-bar so that it's easy to meet new people. Winner of the tournament gets a bar tab. We mainly get about 50-60 backpackers who are staying at hostels around the city.

Free to enter Rock Paper Scissors Tournament & Free Pub Crawl with drink special purchase.

Tournament champion wins a bar tab. Drink Special: Get drink coupons at the first bar so that wells and premium beers are $3 or $3.50 throughout the night. Prizes for best athletic wear.

--> Compete in Rock Paper Scissors tournament qualifying rounds while moving from bar to bar.

--> Top players from qualifying rounds plus several wild card players compete at the final bar. Champion receives a bar tab.

--> Dance Party following tournament.

'Like' us on Facebook *and* RSVP you're attending and get a $1

LIKE US HERE: https://www.facebook.com/beerpubcrawl

RSVP HERE: https://www.facebook.com/beerpubcrawl/events

WHEN: Every WEDNESDAY! WHERE: Meet at NORTHSTAR - 1560 Powell St. (near the corner of Green St), SF

TIME: Signup at 9PM. ***YOU MUST ARRIVE BY 9:30PM TO COMPETE in the rock paper scissors tournament. Pub crawlers/non-tournament players also welcome.

name: Indian Dinner, Comedy Show & BYOB! (EVERY THURSDAY)
description:
NOTE: This is a recurring event that happens every Thursday. The date will change on the event invitation as it gets close to the event starting time, but the event is still happening this Thursday at 7:45PM!

RSVP is *required*. You *must* meet us outside Score Bar (490 Broadway St) between 7:45PM and 8PM if you're planning to attend. Do NOT try to meet up with us after 8PM or you will be turned away.

We'll be heading out with a group of travelers for Indian dinner followed by a live Comedy Show. The Indian restaurant is BYOB, so feel free to bring your own beer, wine, alcohol, etc. Option to also stop at a dueling piano bar and also a popular bar in SF with 100 beers on tap, skeeball & games at the end of the night.

We'll be joining the international travelers group and picking up a groups of backpackers from local hostels - since the menu selections and restaurant changes sometimes, here is the main event link with all the info, the full menu choices for our group, etc:

http://www.meetup.com/SanFranciscoHostel/events/193699332/

EVENT INFO:

www.sfhostelparty.com ( http://www.sfhostelparty.com/ )

$11.75 + $3.25 tax/tip includes entry to Comedy Show (save $15 ticket fee!), and an Indian curry combo meal - includes rice, naan, salad and your choice of two curries (tax & tip are included). Plus you can bring your own booze to the restaurant!

NOTE: The Dinner & Comedy show is all ages. If you're planning to go to the piano bar or the bar with 100 beers, be sure to bring your ID that shows you are 21+. If you have an out of country ID, it is best to bring a passport since some places do not accept international drivers licenses.

=====================================

For choice of Curries & Entrees, see the main event link:

http://www.meetup.com/SanFranciscoHostel/events/193699332/

As this will be a large group, the food choices have been pre-organized - so there are NO ADDITIONAL FOOD SUBSTITUTIONS!

======================================

See you Thursday!

name: AUSTRALIA DAY PARTY & Sausage Sizzle! $3 Beer/Wine, TRIPLE J, Aussie Games!
description:
Aussie Aussie Aussie, Oi Oi Oi! Join us for the Sixth Annual Australia Day Triple J Hottest 100 Beer Olympics Party & Sausage Sizzle! 

NOTE: RSVP IS *REQUIRED* on FACEBOOK for entry and will be checked at the door: http://www.australiadaysf.com/</a>

And here is the link to the main meetup info with time schedule, drink specials, etc: <a href="http://www.meetup.com/SFAussiesKiwisBritsSaffas/events/227947502/">http://www.meetup.com/SFAussiesKiwisBritsSaffas/events/227947502/

Come party with us and a bunch of Aussies on Australia Day! We'll be picking up groups of Australians that are traveling in SF. Celebrate with them over some Aussie themed drinking games, Tim Tam Slams, Two Up, Fairy bread, Thong Toss, the 'Hey Hey It's Saturday' Team Drinking Challenge, and Imported Australian beers - all while listening to TRIPLE J's HOTTEST 100 (streaming live from Australia)! Compete in the Best Dressed Aussie Bogan Contest, build the tallest Didgeridoo (aka: Wizard Staff) out of beer cans, eat some Snags or some Vegemite on Toast, and find some Sheilas. Fair dinkum, mate.

FREE to play in the Games! FREE ENTRY with facebook RSVP *and* $10 towards a Beer/Wine Special Purchase. 

Beer/Wine Special: 5 Beers/Wine for $15 (5-5:20PM); 5 Beers/Wine for $20 (5:20-6PM); 5 Beers/Wine for $25 (AFTER 6PM). Any additional drink special purchases are $5 off! (ie: 5 Beers/Wine for $10 between 5-5:20PM, $15 between 5:20-6PM, $20 after 6PM). 

Plus $1 'Summer Heights High' Shots! 

NOTE: Tournament sign ups for Aussie-themed Drinking Games are from 5PM to 9:30PM. You must arrive by 9:30PM to compete in the tournament and be placed on a team. Everyone's placed on a team based on their country (to make it easy to meet people). Teams compete at Australian-themed games. Play -or- just watch, drink cheap beer/wine and be social!

name: 2019 AFL Grand Final San Francisco Official Party & Sausage Sizzle! $2 Beer/Wine
description:
RSVP REQUIRED on FACEBOOK and will be checked at the door: https://www.facebook.com/events/2001895596561664/

Aussie Aussie Aussie, Oi Oi Oi! Join us for the 2018 AFL Grand Final SF Beer Olympics Watch Party & Sausage Sizzle! Aussie spirit attire encouraged. We'll be meeting up with Aussies from around SF and picking up Aussies that are traveling and staying in the city: https://www.meetup.com/SFAussiesKiwisBritsSaffas/events/254827975/

The 2018 AFL Grand Final will be showing on EVERY TV SCREEN in BOTH Horizon Lounge and Score Sports Bar. Dustin Martin look-alike contest at midnight.

Plus, to encourage everyone to meet new people, you'll be added to a team to compete for your country in Aussie-themed Beer Olympics tournament games that start during halftime in the Horizon Lounge. Enjoy Tim Tam Slams, Fairy bread, and Vegemite on Toast. Enter the Best Dressed Aussie Bogan Contest, build the tallest Didgeridoo (aka: Wizard Staff) out of beer cans, eat some Snags, and find some Sheilas. Fair dinkum, mate.

FREE ENTRY with RSVP *AND* $5 towards Beer/Wine/Spirit Special Purchase.

5 Beers/Wine for $10 (6-6:20PM & 9-9:20PM); 5 Beers/Wine for $15 (9:20-9:40PM); 5 Beers/Wine for $20 (All other times!). Plus cheap wells/house spirits all night. There will also be other discounts offered on imported Australian beers while supplies last.

Aussie-themed games include: 'Down Under' Beer Pong, Two-Up, Boomerang Flip, Ayers Rock Paper Scissors, and Build the tallest Beer Can Didgeridoo (aka: Wizard Staff). Win Prizes! FREE to play in the games. Meet/Compete against Aussies, international travelers, locals, au pairs and students.
--> Everyone's placed on a team based on your country (to make it easy to meet people).

name: Monday Night Games
Monday Night Games!
Beer.js SF
description:
By design, Beer.js SF is a super casual meetup. No presentations, nametags, or sponsors. It's just a bunch of social software nerds meeting up at a bar to talk about awesome things, tech and non-tech related. Think of it as the meetup after the meetup, but without the first meetup. Make sense? Cool! Come, hang out, have a beer (or even a non-alcoholic drink), and partake in some great conversations with us!

We typically meet up in the craft beer bar (The Willows has two) where Tom is bartending.

name: Critique and Print
description:
Host: Celac Colvert
Registration Link:
https://www.regonline.com/registration/Checkin.aspx?EventID=2535074

This event is a great opportunity to bring your digital image files for critique by our Canon expert, Jim Rose. Jim will project your images for the group to see so he can best explain ways to improve such items like composition, lighting, exposure and use of color. He will also be printing one of your favorite images to take home on our professional PIXMA PRO-1 printer. Enjoy an evening with Canon to learn how to improve your style of photography, and perhaps get new ideas and inspiration from viewing the work of others.

What you will learn:

• Canon expert will critique your images and give constructive criticism on what could be improved. Your peers will also weigh in on which is their favorite of your three images.
• Learn great ideas from others as well as find new and exciting places to explore your photography.

What to bring:

• Three files (jpeg or tiff) sized at 13'’x19” at 300 ppi (pixels per inch) on a flash drive
• Create a folder with your name and place the files in that folder
• Bring something to carry your print

name: Architechture Photo Walk and Print
description:
Host: Celac Colvert
Fee: $99
Registration Link:
https://www.regonline.com/registration/Checkin.aspx?EventID=2535108

San Francisco is one of the most beautiful cities in the world and full of interesting buildings. This photo walk will concentrate on capturing the character and personality of some of the city’s best architecture. Canon Live Learning instructor, Celac Colvert, will lead this photo walk in San Francisco’s Financial District.

We’ll begin at the Canon Live Learning classroom with a short discussion on architectural photography and then head out in the Financial District to make great images.

The class will continue back in the Live Learning classroom with a discussion on the techniques discussed and evaluate our results. Finally you will be able to make a print from your favorite image on Canon’s imagePROFGFAF PRO-1000 Professional Inkjet printer.

Don’t miss this unique walking photography workshop and learn
Workshop space is very limited so sign up now!

What to bring:

• Your camera and lenses
• Freshly charged batteries
• Empty and formatted memory cards
• Tripod and remote release (cable or infrared)
• Comfortable walking shoes

name: Creative Portraits Using Colored Gels
description:
Host: Laura Tillinghast
Fee: $49
Registration Link:
https://www.regonline.com/registration/Checkin.aspx?EventID=2535110

A well-executed dramatic portrait has that special something that makes it memorable.

But how can we achieve drama while still creating a flattering look? In this hands-on workshop with Laura Tillinghast, you will learn her techniques for creating stunning dramatic portraits using Speedlites and colored gels. You will also learn how Laura poses and works with her subjects to get the best images possible.

Bring your camera for a chance to shoot with the model during the class.

What you will learn:

• Dramatic lighting using colored gels
• Accent lighting techniques
• Posing strategies

What to bring with you:

• Camera & memory card

name: Hands On Macro Workshop
description:
Host: Jim Rose
Fee: $49
Registation Link:
https://www.regonline.com/registration/Checkin.aspx?EventID=2535112

Join us at Canon Live Learning San Francisco for a hands-on workshop exploring the world of macro photography.

This class is limited in size so everyone has the opportunity to photograph all of the subjects we have set up.

This is an inspiring macro class with a lot of new concepts. Please feel free to bring your own subjects to shoot as well – whether your interest is in photographing industrial parts, coins, natural history specimens, jewelry, or botanicals.

What to bring:

• Your camera, flash and macro lens (macro gear will also be available)
• Freshly charged batteries
• Extra formatted memory cards
• Tripod
• Remote release cable
• Macro Subjects (optional)

name: Birds of Prey in Flight
description:
Fee: $149
Registration Link:
https://www.regonline.com/registration/Checkin.aspx?EventID=2535114

This event sold out last time, so register now.

Canon Live Learning presents a photographic workshop: “Birds of Prey In Flight”. Don’t miss this opportunity to photograph hawks, falcons, and owls in flight!

Capturing birds in flight can create challenges for the photographer. Canon Live Learning instructors Jim Rose and Dave Henry will be on hand to instruct you in the proper camera setting and shooting techniques you will need to get the best images possible. We will also have loaner cameras and lens available for all to use.

Raptors that we will photograph in flight include:
• Harris Hawk
• Aplomado Flacon
• Lanner/Saker Hybrid Falcon
• Owls
Time permitting we will also be able to photograph any of the birds at the center.

What you will learn:
• Autofocus settings for birds in flight
• How to use picture styles to control contrast
• Menu items for action subjects

What to bring with you:
• Camera & memory card
• Fully charged batteries
• Telephoto lens
• Monopod (not required)
• Canon cameras and lenses will be available

name: WomenHack - The All-Women Hackathon San Francisco
description:
TO ATTEND THIS MEETUP, YOU NEED TO PURCHASE A TICKET ON EVENTBRITE: https://womenhack18.eventbrite.com/

A one-day hackathon for women from experienced coders to total newbies.

Join our Hackathon Event FB page for updates and to connect with other participants.

Only 20% of hackathon participants are women, similar in scope to the underrepresentation of women in computer science and other tech fields.

For the last two years, The Expat Woman has been addressing this gender gap by hosting incredible all-women hackathons in San Francisco. All our hackathons have been sold out events with participants developing innovative websites, games, cloud-based services, or mobile apps to address various challenges.

Join us on the occasion of International Women's Day, for our fourth All-Women Hackathon. The hackathon will be part of EMPOWERED - The Women's Leadership Summit on March 24, 2018, at Galvanize, San Francisco.

Come with an idea, and form a team or join a team on-site and spend the day building a great project with enthusiastic, talented fun people.

Registration | We have limited slots available, so please sign-up here. Your registration fee covers all meals (breakfast, lunch, and dinner)

Teams | Teams of 6 women will be formed Saturday morning.

Judges | Our judging panel is made up of industry influencers, educators, hackathon pros and civic leaders.

Bring |Your laptop, skills & ideas. Come with a collaborative, team-focused mindset and/or team-up in advance on Twitter/Facebook with #tewhack.

Food, fun, and prizes.

Hackathon Challenges

Engage more Girls in STEM

End the Gender Gap in Tech

Design a Blockchian or Crypto Business or Solution

Women’s Empowerment

Help Immigrant/Refugee women or children Navigate the US

If you have coding/hackathon experience and are interested in volunteering as a mentor, please register here

For sponsorship, prizes or demo table inquiries, please e-mail us at [masked]

We have four Winning Categories

1. Originality: How unique is your idea

2. Technical: Best use of code to create your product

3. Design: Best looking product

4. Business Model: Is there a viable business model attached to the idea

Agenda
9:00am- 10:30am egistration, breakfast, team & idea forming, and kickoff

10:30am - 1pm work on project

1:00pm - lunch and continue working on project

6:30pm - 7:30pm dinner and final project submission deadline

7:30 - 10:30pm - introductions, hackathon presentations and awards

"What an incredible day. Thanks for all you did to pull it off - it was by far the best hackathon I've ever attended. So well-organized, and tons of talented, impressive women to connect with. I really appreciate all the work you and your team poured in to make the day so great!"- Ginny Fahs, Full Stack Software Developer and Sept. 2017 WomenHack participant

If you are interested in participating as a panelist, speaker or mentor at our events, please apply here

Terms of Participation Agreement

You agree that you are responsible for any accidents or damages that you cause. You also agree to not hold The Expat Woman, or any of the event supporters liable for any loss, damage, injury, or any other unforeseeable incident.

You agree The Expat Woman, is not responsible for circumstances that may necessitate for substitutions or cancellations of speakers.

By Participating at the event, you grant The Expat Woman permission to capture photos/videos of the event.

By registering for this event, you also consent to receive email communication from The Expat Woman and its programs about events and updates that may interest you.

Tickets to this event are non-refundable. If you are unable to attend, you have the option of giving it to a friend or team member to attend in your place.

name: Breaking the Glass Ceiling: Women Tech Leaders in SV Panel @Yelp
description:
To attend this event, you need to register on Eventbrite: https://womentechsv.eventbrite.com/

Join us for an inspiring and empowering evening of networking, and a panel discussion with women who are making huge strides in the Tech industry. They will share their stories, the obstacles they’ve overcome, and their hopes for the future of the industry.

The event is open to women and men of all professional backgrounds.

Talk with industry movers and shakers, make professional contacts, share experiences with your peers and get inspired to take the next steps in your career.

The event is open to women and men of all professional backgrounds.

Astha Malik, VP of Platform and Product Marketing at Zendesk

name: Strategy Board Game Night: Scythe - [SOMA]
description:
This is a weekly game night that focuses on games in the medium to heavy strategy range. Everyone is welcome to join, even if you are inexperienced with strategy games. However, you must be patient and willing to learn these great games.

This week we are continue the Scythe series started last week. We previously played the base game with the Invaders from Afar expansion. This week I am adding "The Wind Gambit" expansion. Next week we will start a playthrough of the Rise of Fenris campaign. If you're reading this I hope you join because it will be a great experience! :D

Note: If you're new to Scythe and have 30 minutes to spare please watch this great tutorial video for the game. Thanks! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ffMLIL5qGQg

Currently, we will play one game per night. If you are interested in teaching another game at a second table we can accommodate that as well. Please get in touch with me.

Let's play!

There is plenty of parking on 9th St.
Civic Center BART is 3 minutes away.

Make sure to call me at[masked] when you get here.

Snacks or drinks to share

name: Halloween Spooktacular III: Haunted Mansion dance party at Dada Bar
description:
This event is organized by Urban Adventure Club, in partnership with SF Game Nights. Gamers get 50% off tickets!

Halloween is almost here! Urban Adventure Club and SF Game Nights is bringing you another epic dance party! Put on your best costume and enjoy a night of party music, delicious drinks, fun games, and epic dancing with all your friends at Urban Adventure Club and SF Game Nights!

The party will be at Dada Bar, a cocktail bar/art gallery/event space that's perfect for our party. We've rented out the entire venue so we can have the bar to ourselves for the whole night. It's spacious, has a huge bar, and lots of room for mingling and dancing.

This year's party will be bigger and better and spookier than our past parties. You can look forward to:
- Dada Bar turned into a haunted mansion for the party
- A cash bar with special Halloween cocktail list for extra delicious spookiness
- A DJ to keep you dancing all night long!
- A photo booth to take pictures with your friends in your awesome costumes
- Halloween party games to make you laugh and SCREAM!
- Free Halloween candy and party favors for all the guests
- And there will be a scary surprise around midnight...
Come join the fun and make it a night you won't forget, or can't remember... =D

Click Here to Follow Our Events Calendar (https://www.calendarx.com/calendarpage/cw71248)

Ticket price
Early bird ticket $20.00 (Limited)
Regular ticket $30.00
Last minute ticket $40.00

SF Game Night members get 50% off all tickets. Use promo code: SFGAMENIGHT

Buy your ticket here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/urban-adventure-club-halloween-spooktacular-iii-tickets-51046084212

You must show your ticket to enter the party
Tickets are limited and may not be available at the door

The Plan:
9:00 PM: Party starts at Dada Bar
10:00 PM: Halloween party games, photo booth, and cocktails!
11:00 PM: Start the dance party!
12:00 PM: Halloween party surprise
2:00 AM: After party

name: Sunday Evening Pickup Soccer
Friday Pickup Soccer
The Fall Ball - Largest SF Singles Dance of the Season!
description:

description:
This will be about a 6 mile hike - Moderate (depending on your condition), w/ roughly a 1250' elevation gain, taking in Cataract Creek, Cataract Falls, Laurel Dell, Potrero Picnic Area, Potrero Meadow, and possibly a couple other spots. We'll see where we get ;-) ... A lot will depend on the group and how chill or not you're feeling.

What To Bring:

Vino! (and cups)

Good Hiking Boots/shoes

Layered clothing, hat, sunscreen.

Vino & Snacks for our pre-lunch vino\snack break. Energy bars are highly recommended.

Food for the potluck: (packed w/ carbs) and more food I.E. wraps, cut up sandwiches, cheeses/breads/crackers, dried fruit/nuts, chips, dips, use your imagination.

At least 1 liter of water (2 is better) Fill w/ 1/2 water & 1/2 ice.

Anything else you want to drink (juice, tea, beer, etc.)

$5 activity fee

You probably know what to expect by now

Normally there's plenty of food - so what happened?

Some people get really excited on this one.

Please note: This hike is completely different than "From The Dam Up" - we will not be on that side of Tam today.

GPS[masked],[masked]

Your sense of humour is an absolute must!

This hike is posted to several Meetup grps, so this is a good opportunity to make new friends.

See you there!

name: Michael Stocker:Evidence of Synchronous Chorusing in North Atlantic Minke Whales
description:
Admission: donations are encouraged, $10 general, $5 students

Join us for a fascinating presentation by Michael Stocker, Executive Director of Ocean Conservation Research, as he brings us into the world of North Atlantic minke whale vocalizations.

Many rorquals (blue, fin, sei, Brydes, and minke whales) communicate with pulses in the low and infrasonic frequency ranges. Research indicates that minke whales synchronize their pulsing with others, forming a chorus. Michael will introduce us to how this was discovered and why minke whales might be communicating in this manner.

Click for more info:
https://www.acs-sfbay.org/events/2018/10/23/michael-stocker-evidence-of-synchronous-chorusing-in-north-atlantic-minke-whales

#whale #soundscapes #minkewhale #oceansounds

name: Michelle Modest: “Humpback Whale Migratory Routes, Foraging to Breeding Grounds”
description:
Please join the ACS San Francisco Chapter for this fascinating presentation by Michelle Modest: “Examining Southern Hemisphere Humpback Whale Migratory Routes from Foraging to Breeding Grounds”.

Free of charge, donations are welcome.

Southern hemisphere humpback whale populations spend a large portion of the year breeding in tropical waters and migrating between this region and their summer feeding grounds in the Antarctic. They travel great distances during their seasonal migration, the farthest migration of any mammal, with distances up to 11,706 miles recorded. Despite this impressive feat, minimal information is known about their migratory journeys. We have tagged numerous humpback whales with ARGOS satellite tags in the Antarctic feeding grounds over the past several years and have collected data on complete tracks from Antarctica to the western coast of South America. This is the first study to examine humpback whale migratory routes from foraging to breeding grounds, and one of the few to have a workable sample size. We will use this information to create a comprehensive overview of migratory behaviors and characteristics.

Biography:

Michelle Modest originally hails from State College, Pennsylvania. She received her BA from Yale University, and then went on Imperial College London to complete an MSc in Conservation Science. At Imperial, she worked with Brandon Southall to complete her thesis titled Anthropogenic noise pollution: Understanding the effects of mid-frequency active sonar on Risso’s dolphin behavior. She is now a first year PhD student in Ari Friedlaender’s lab at UC Santa Cruz, and is very excited to spend the next 5 years investigating the effects of climate change on humpback whales in the Western Antarctic Peninsula.

name: Kris Palmer, flute and Varvara Milinder, piano
description:
Date & Time: Saturday October 13, 2018 at 7:30 pm
Venue:[masked]th Avenue, San Francisco
Tickets: $20 General, $15 Seniors/Students

For more information or to buy tickets online visit https://sunsetarts.wordpress.com/kris-palmer-flute-and-varvara-milinder-piano-in-concert/

Program
Eldin Burton [masked])
Sonatina

Georg Friedrich Händel [masked])
Flute Sonata in G Major, HWV 363

Albert Franz Doppler [masked])
Fantaisie Pastorale Hongroise, Opus 26

About the Artists

A first-prize winner in the Carmel Chamber Music Society Competition, Dr. Kris Palmer is the director and founder of Black Cedar, a rare ensemble devoted to music for flute, cello, and guitar. Under her leadership, the trio has garnered multiple grants from the San Francisco Friends of Chamber Music and the Zellerbach Family Foundation, commissioned four new works for this unique instrumental combination, released an album of new and re-discovered trios, and earned an invitation to the National Flute Association Convention. “You can easily see why this unique group has become a chamber music draw in the musically rich Bay Area,” writes James Manheim of AllMusic.com.

As a solo artist, Dr. Palmer made her New York recital debut at Carnegie Hall in 2001 to rave reviews as a winner in the Artists International Competition. The New York Concert Review called Palmer’s performance “incisive and expressive…particularly enchanting…with sensuous tone and pace.” Dr. Palmer is a second-prize winner in the National Flute Association’s Young Artist Competition, a first-prize winner in the Ruth Burr Awards in Houston, a fourth-prize winner in the Cynthia Woods Mitchell Young Artist Competition in Texas, and a finalist in both the Hemphill-Wells Sorantin Young Artist Awards in Texas and the William C. Byrd Competition in Michigan. Her solo album, Versailles, is a compilation of her own arrangements of French Baroque works. The New York Concert Review says, “She is clearly among the few current performers on any instrument to fully understand the nature of French Baroque music.”

Dr. Palmer holds a Doctorate of Musical Arts with an emphasis in eighteenth-century performance practice from Rice University, where she worked as a teaching assistant for seven years. She is the author of the book, Ornamentation According to C.P.E. Bach and J.J. Quantz, and the American Music Teacher magazine writes, “Clearly, the author is knowledgeable about ornamentation.” She also holds a Master of Music from Rice University and a Bachelor of Music from the University of Southern California. Her primary teachers are Carol Wincenc, John Thorne, Aralee Dorough, the late Roger S. Stevens, Walfrid Kujala, Anne Diener Zentner, Leone Buyse, and Gaetano Schiavone with the Conservatory of Santa Cecilia in Rome.

Dr. Palmer is a former member of the New Mexico Symphony Orchestra – where she served as assistant principal flute, the Chamber Orchestra of Albuquerque – where she held the position of principal flute, and the Debut Orchestra of Los Angeles – where she held the position of second flute. She currently performs as principal flutist with Island City Opera, and she has performed with Houston Symphony, Santa Cruz Symphony, Santa Cruz Ballet, Modesto Symphony, Monterey Symphony, Shreveport Symphony, Ohio Light Opera Company, and Lamplighters Operetta Company.

name: Chamber concert with the Rimsky-Korsakov String Quartet, St. Petersburg, Russia
description:
The Rimsky-Korsakov String Quartet from St. Petersburg, Russia, returns to Sunset Music & Arts in the fall for another exciting program for the string quartet. The quartet will be joined by guest artist, mezzo-soprano, Sally Porter Munro.

Date & Time: Thursday October 25, 7:30 p.m.
Venue:[masked]th Avenue, San Francisco
Tickets: $20 General, $15 Seniors/Students

For more information visit https://sunsetarts.wordpress.com/rimsky-korsakov-string-quartet-3/

About Rimsky-Korsakov String Quartet

The Rimsky-Korsakov String Quartet, formed in 1939, is a monument of Russian musical history. Composed of four graduates from the prestigious St. Petersburg Conservatory, they regularly perform in the most reputable festivals in Russia, Germany, France, Italy, Malta, England, Switzerland and Finland. Their varied repertoire, ranging from Russian music of the 19th and early 20th centuries to contemporary composers, is enthusiastically enjoyed by a wide range of audiences.

Mikhail Bondarev (violin) graduated in 1983 from the Saint Petersburg Conservatory where he studied violin with Elena Komarova and quartet performance with Vladimir Ovcharek. Previously, he graduated from the Rimsky-Korsakov Specialized Music School where he studied violin with Lev Rankov and Boris Gutnikov. He has been a member of the Rimsky-Korsakov Quartet since 1981.

Ekaterina Belisova (violin), born in Saint Petersburg, started learning the violin at the age of 7 under the supervision of L. A. Ivaschenko. She graduated from the Specialized Music School in 1981 and enrolled at the Saint Petersburg Conservatory where she studied violin with Professor E. A. Komarova, chamber music with Professor T. L. Fidler, and quartet with Vladimir Ovcharek. In 1984, while being a 3rd year student at the Conservatory Ms. Belisova joined the Rimsky-Korsakov quartet. She also performs with other chamber music groups including a piano trio and a piano quartet.

Alexei Popov (viola) finished his education at the Rimsky-Korsakov Specialized Music College in the class of G. M. Hoserova before studying at the Saint Petersburg Conservatory in the classes of Professors Kramarov and Stopichev. He studied quartet performance with Professor Ovcharek, and chamber music with Professor Fidler. At his last year at the Conservatory, in 1985, A. Popov was invited to play at the Rimsky-Korsakov quartet where he is playing at present. Mr. Popov does not limit himself to performances with the quartet, and he often plays chamber music in other ensembles. Mr. Popov’s repertoire comprises of works by J. S. Bach, F. Schubert, M. Glinka, J. Brahms; trios by F. Haydn, works by Mozart, Schumann, and works by 20th century composers. For several years Mr. Popov taught classes for string quartet performance at the Saint-Petersburg State Conservatory, however, during the last years he fully returned to the concert activity.

Anton Andreev (cello) has been a member of the Rimsky-Korsakov quartet since 2008 and has studied cello at the Saint-Petersburg Conservatory with Professor A. P. Nikitin. He is a winner of the Saint-Petersburg Cello Competition (1993), the all-Russia competition (Ryazan, 2000), a diploma winner of the Dotzauer International Competition for Young Cellists (Dresden, 2001), the Mravinsky International Competition (Saint-Petersburg, 2003), and he is a winner of the Shostakovich competition (Saint-Petersburg, 2006). Andreev participated in the Berg master class (Salzburg, 2007, 2008), and the music festivals of Schleswig-Holstein, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern (Germany), and Salzburg (Austria).

Sally Porter Munro (mezzo-soprano) is a native of London, England and a graduate of the Royal Northern College of Music, Manchester, England. While living in England she sang with the English National Opera, Royal Opera de la Monnaie in Brussels, and as an oratorio soloist in Europe. She also performed with the BBC Singers on radio and television. She relocated to New York City to continue her studies.

name: MCD Design Lab: Material Alchemy •• LIMITED SPACE
description:
On the Saturday before All Hallows eve, join the Museum of Craft and Design to immerse yourself in the magical moment between the seen and the unseen!

Inspired by the materials and methods of Raw Design, local artist Ramekon O'Arwisters will lead participants in a dynamic art-making experience that will transform your perceptions of the creative process through a hands on exploration of unexpected materials and the unconscious.

Jump out of the literal and open yourself up to the alchemy of intuition in order to reveal your own unique creative vision! Participants will leave with new connections, altered perspectives and a sculptural crochet take-away.

Ramekon O'Arwisters is a social practice artist represented by the Patricia Sweetow Gallery in San Francisco. He is the founder of Crochet Jam and has held several Artist in Residence positions including Recology and the de Young, as well as enjoyed a professional career (now retired) as a curator of photography at the SFO museum.

Workshop, materials, exhibition access and light refreshments included. All ages welcome.

Space is limited. Tickets must be purchased in advance.

description:

Venue:[masked]th Avenue, San Francisco

For more information visit https://sunsetarts.wordpress.com/othello-jefferson-organ-in-concert/

Program
Works by J.S. Bach, Mathias, Mendelssohn, Parry, Wood, and Young

About the Artist

Othello Jefferson is a native of San Francisco. He received his Bachelor of Music Degree in Voice from the San Francisco Conservatory of Music and a Single Subject Music Credential from San Francisco State University. As Choir Director at his alma mater, Lowell High School, he worked with Michael Morgan (Oakland Symphony), The King’s Singers, and Chanticleer and won performance awards in the International Children’s Culture and Art Festival in Shenzhen, China.

Othello is the recipient of a Gospel Music Award from San Francisco’s Academy of Gospel and a Negro Spirituals Heritage Keepers Award from the Friends Of Negro Spirituals in Oakland. He also recently completed the first level of the American Guild Of Organist’s examinations for professional certification (Service Playing Certificate). His organ teacher is Jerome Lenk, Director of Music and Organist for Mission Dolores Basilica in San Francisco.

Othello is the Choir Director at Sequoia High School and Organist/ Accompanist for Ragazzi Boys Chorus (both in Redwood City). He is also Minister Of Music at First African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church (San Francisco).

description:

They have an awesome community garden located in the parking lot right out side the kitchen.

We will be serving a dinner during the early shift that starts at 4:45 p.m. We will also help with set up and clean up. Please wear close toed shoes and PLEASE arrive at 4:45 p.m. We get the ball rolling fairly quickly and it helps if we are all there at the same time.

Thank you everyone for your continued support in supplying ECS with much needed helping hands!

Please make sure to wear close toed shoes, sleeved shirts and pants!

description:
Serve dinner to those in need in our community. The Next Door Shelter (a program of Episcopal Community Services/ECS) is the largest 24-hour emergency homeless shelter in San Francisco. Home to 340 people every day and night. Many people staying in the shelter are seniors, vets and individuals with disabilities. ECS is the largest provider of homeless shelter services in SF. The meal service is split in two shifts and Get Volunteering will be serving dinner during the second shift from 6:15 - 7:45 pm. When you enter the building you will be signing in at the front desk and heading to the lower level dining room. There will be stairs right in front of you or the elevator will be to your right past the reception desk.

Come out to volunteer and make some new friends!

name: March to your polling place & VOTE
description:
GO VOTE (or Vote-by-Mail)

- Take someone with you, check with neighbors in case they need a ride or help getting to their polling place

- We have some people in our nation that do not have this privilege so make sure your vote is intersectional and that you are not just looking out for your community, but for all of your sisters, brothers and non-binary communities, especially our marginalized communities which are under attack.

---
Here is the website with information for San Francisco:
https://sfelections.sfgov.org/key-election-dates-and-deadlines-voters

Polling places, the City Hall Voting Center, and Vote-by-Mail ballot drop-off stations are open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m.
8 p.m. Deadline for Personal Delivery of Vote-by-Mail Ballots
Ballots that are personally delivered must be received by 8 p.m. on Election Day.
8 p.m. Deadline for Faxed Ballots
Last day a military or overseas voter who is living outside the U.S. may return a ballot by fax. Faxed ballots must be received by 8 p.m. on Election Day and must be accompanied by an Oath of Voter.

name: Dawnland: Screening and Panel
description:
Join us on Friday November 16, 2018 at The Commonwealth Club of California, Taube Family Auditorium [110 The Embarcadero, San Francisco]
5:30 p.m. check-in with light refreshments and cash bar
6:30 p.m. program starts with a panel hosted by Women’s March San Francisco and then followed by the screening of Dawnland.

Tickets sold by Commonwealth Club is REQUIRED for Entry: https://www.commonwealthclub.org/events/2018-11-16/dawnland-screening-and-discussion

For most of the 20th century, the U.S. government systematically forced Native American children from their homes and placed them with white families. Even as recently as the 1970s, one in four Native children nationwide was living in non-Native foster care, adoptive homes or boarding schools. Many of these children experienced devastating emotional and physical harm from adults who mistreated them and tried to erase their cultural identity.

Dawnland, a feature-length documentary, follows the first government-sanctioned truth and reconciliation commission in the United States. The film tracks the commission’s journey across Maine, to gather testimony and bear witness to the devastating impact of the State’s child welfare practices on families in Maliseet, Micmac, Passamaquoddy and Penobscot tribal communities. Collectively, these tribes make up the Wabanaki people.

Prior to the screening, Women’s March San Francisco will host a panel moderated by Michelle Meow to hear directly from members of the Native American community about how their families were impacted by these atrocious acts, and we will explore parallels to similar atrocities happening today with immigrant families being separated at our borders.

Please join us for this informative discussion and screening of this important film, get your Commonwealth Club tickets here (required for entry): https://www.commonwealthclub.org/events/2018-11-16/dawnland-screening-and-discussion

Moderator: Michelle Meow from "The Michelle Meow Show" (KBCW TV and Progressive Voices Network Radio)

Panelists TBA soon...........

WMSF is a 100% volunteer run organization, we do not get any funding from WM National (DC Chapter) and we rely solely on donations from our community to help us cover the costs for our programming, actions, events, marches and rallies. Tickets for this event go to The Commonwealth Club and WMSF doesn't receive any percentage of the ticket sales. Please help us by making a Donations at https://womensmarchbayarea.org/donate/
Any amount helps!

Thank you and in solidarity,
Women's March San Francisco Leadership Team

name: The Courage to be Imperfect - Meditation Workshop
description:
Look perfect. Do perfect. Be perfect. Perfectionism at its best leads to excellence and great results. But too much perfectionism is toxic and not so perfect!

If you want to strive for authenticity, happiness and progress, embrace your imperfections and be perfectly, imperfect.

Join us to explore how to develop the courage to be imperfect.

Everyone is welcome to attend and no prior meditation experience is required. Your voluntary donations are appreciated.

401 Baker Street (at Hayes)
San Francisco, CA

name: Power Up Your Optimism - Meditation Workshop
description:
Do you look on the bright side of life or see the downside? Do you see the opportunity in every difficulty or the difficulty in every opportunity? Focus on the possibilities or the impossibilities?

How you choose to see things, influences your decisions and actions and, as a result, affects the outcome. If you want to give yourself a better chance for success, turn on your optimism.

Optimism is energizing, it fuels you and powers you up. Research shows that optimists are genuinely happier, healthier and wealthier.

So, if the glass is half empty, fill the other half with optimism. Change your outlook, power down pessimism and power up your optimism. Join us for tips on how.

Everyone is welcome to attend and no prior meditation experience is required. Your voluntary donations are appreciated.

401 Baker Street (at Hayes)
San Francisco, CA

The event features both women and men from a variety of sectors sharing their perspectives and challenging our assumptions.

During the event, six female-led entrepreneurs will pitch their innovative cleantech or sustainability-focused business idea to a panel of industry leaders. name: How can we bootstrap interpretation?
description:
Last week we considered the dependence or independence of meaning and communication. This week we'll consider a related question. How can we, by communication and context, and without prior common language or culture, come to know meaning? This has been called radical interpretation, or radical translation. We'll read David Lewis's analysis, in some part as a response to Grice, titled "Radical Interpretation".

http://andrewmbailey.com/dkl/Radical_Interpretation.pdf
https://philpapers.org/rec/LEWRI

name: Seminar II
description: For our bi-weekly weekday seminar, we slowly work our way through a number of books, in parallel, each oriented around the interests of one of us. Currently these include books on perception, language, mind, normativity, and modal logic.

name: Seminar I
description: For our weekly Sunday seminar, we typically read a single article, or sometimes a book over the course of several weeks. Beginners are welcome but the material is not elementary, as we are all beginners in this impossible tradition. As Peter Strawson wrote, there is "no shallow end to the philosophical pool".

name: Solidity Saturdays: P2P Learning
description:
Come join your friends at the SF Ethereum Meetup for Solidity Saturdays!
We're building a top notch peer-to-peer learning community around the Solidity programming language and working with the Ethereum blockchain.

No Solidity experience is necessary (but it would be great if you've coded in something). Pure interest goes a long way.

For starters, we run through CryptoZombies game. It's a great primer on the language: http://www.cryptozombies.io

From there, we're still tinkering. There is so much innovation going on and so much work to be done. Honestly, the most effective means of collectively growing out of the basics is an open question. Some valuable resources as well...

• SpaceDoggos: https://www.bitdegree.org/courses/learn-solidity-space-doggos/
• Ethernaut: https://ethernaut.zeppelin.solutions/
• Ethereum Pet Shop: http://truffleframework.com/tutorials/pet-shop

If you've got a project you're working on or something you'd like to further your understanding of with others, please bring it!

If you'd like to help others with their projects, come on down!

Bring your laptops!

Telegram supergroup for this event:
https://t.me/sf_ethereum_ss

Solidity Saturdays is a part of Distributed Saturdays: A weekly blockchain & protocol-agnostic learning fest for all knowledge-levels, technical and non-technical.
____________________________________________

ABOUT STARFISH MISSION
Starfish Mission is a blockchain centric co-working space inspired by the passion of the local Bay Area blockchain community. The organization’s mission is to inspire collaboration, promote education, and strengthen unity amongst those who seek to change the world for good using blockchain and decentralized ledger technology.

Be a member of the Starfish Network and work alongside other blockchain buidlers. Host an event, teach a class, book a desk or rent an office. You'll thank your lucky starfish that you joined.

Contact info @ starfish.network or visit http://starfish.network/

name: Proof of Steak! A Potluck-Agnostic Picnic for All Our Friends (Partner Event)
description:
We've come to a consensus that we need to mine some of the last rays of Summer with all our blockchain and crypto friends before the chilling cold pulls a 51% attack on our weather.

From the looks of it, it seems like it's all about the meat, but it's actually a POTLUCK-AGNOSTIC picnic, so bring both meat and/or veggies to grill.
We'll have a separate pan and gas grill that's veggie friendly, but only if needed. (Let us know!)

BRING FRIENDS!

WHERE IS IT AT?
• Golden Gate Park, Hellman Hollow, Tables 5 and 6 (near the East Meadow)

WHAT WILL HAPPEN AT THE PICNIC?
Outside of the usual picnic stuff, there will be...
• Games like, "You can't say 'Blockchain', 'Layer 2', 'Web 3.0' or 'Code'" and prizes.
• Music (maybe the live acoustic kind hopefully)
• Bring a friend who wants to know more about blockchain. I'm down to explain, and will point them to the right person if I can't answer their questions.

WHAT TO BRING
• Whatever food you want grilled / to grill
• Your grill master skillz, if you have any
• Sides
• Desserts
• Snacks
• Your favorite beer and wine to share
• Your guitar, ukelele, juggling gear...whatever talent you have that's safe and appropriate to share at a picnic
• A friend or 2 (does not have to be in the blockchain space)
• Picnic Blankets
• Blankets to wrap yourself in in case Karl the Fog comes in early
• Footballs, Soccer Balls, Dodge Balls, Rum Balls

WE'LL BRING
• Utensils
• Plates
• Napkins
• Trash bags
• Cooler
• Ice
• Bluetooth Speaker
• Beer/wine openers
• Grilling utensils, chopping board
• Gas grill and pans if needed

~

HOW TO CONTACT US ON THE DAY OF
• Please join our friends at Starfish on the Starfish Telegram page: https://t.me/starfishnetwork and message us there.
• Map of Hellman Hollow with Table 5 & 6 locations will be posted at this Telegram.

~

NOT-SO-SMALL SMALL PRINT FROM THE GGP PEEPS
• Please bag and remove all your trash completely out of the park (aka, "Pack it in! Pack it out!")
• No amplified sound allowed.
• Nothing is to be tied, taped, attached to, or staked into the trees, grass or the ground.
• All vehicles must stay on the street. Permitee advised to arrive early to secure parking spot as spaces are not guaranteed. No driving or parking on grass or inside the park; not even for loading or unloading. All rentals & equipment must be hand-carried to site.
• No extra time will be given outside of permitted time (9am to 6pm).

Enjoy luminosity, great music, curated food trucks and beer and wine service hosted by We Bring The Bar.

Please buy your tickets before the event

--------- Featured Beers -----------

Social Kitchen and Brewery – Makers of award winning beers, elevated pub fare, and innovative cocktails. Located in SF’s Inner Sunset district next to Golden Gate Park.

Temescal Brewing – Temescal Brewing is a North Oakland production brewery, tasting room, and beer garden. We make refreshing beer for curious people and we take pride in showing off another side of brewing, one that is softer, lighter, more understated and approachable—be it a patio-sipping Pilsner, a velvety Scotch ale, or a juicy IPA.

name: Hiking in Muir Woods
description:
https://www.nps.gov/planyourvisit/fee-free-parks.htm

Fee-free days make national parks accessible to more people.

Come experience the national parks! On four days in 2018, all National Park Service sites that charge an entrance fee will offer free admission to everyone.

National parks are America’s best idea, and there are more than 400 parks available to everyone, every day. The fee-free days provide a great opportunity to visit a new place or an old favorite, especially one of the national parks that normally charge an entrance fee. The others are free all the time. The entrance fee waiver for fee-free days does not cover amenity or user fees for activities such as camping, boat launches, transportation, or special tours.

The annual $80 America the Beautiful National Parks and Federal Recreational Lands Pass allows unlimited entrance to more than 2,000 federal recreation areas, including all national parks that normally charge an entrance fee. There are also free or discounted passes available for senior citizens, current members of the military, families of fourth-grade students, and disabled citizens. Learn more about the variety of passes offered by the America the Beautiful National Parks and Federal Recreational Lands Pass series.

name: Hacknight: We are playing with things like WebXR, EEG, Oculus GO, and Tensorflow
description:
Hacknight: We are playing with things like WebXR, EEG, Oculus GO, Raspberry Pi Zero W, MySQL, Tensorflow, and Blockchain. Lets Study WebXR for Brain Computer Interfaces.

The latest updates: https://medium.com/silicon-valley-global-news/noisebridge-went-to-the-maker-faire-in-this-article-you-will-learn-about-ngalac-the-93f4857d3014

Ring Door Bell to get in. We are on the Mission St side of Noisebridge near the windows https://www.noisebridge.net/wiki/Getting_Here

Updates: We have successfully achieved connecting EEG to the Oculus Go via WebVR, we have also integrated FFT (Fast fourier transform) into the code, we are collecting time stamped user action data, and time stamped eeg data for the neural network portion of the project. We have replaced the original server written in Python with a new server written in GO.

How can we visualize biofeedback VR in 3D with WebXR? How can we collect user data to train Neural Networks?

You can optionally bring your own VR headset, laptop, and EEG device.

Watch the Neural Lace Podcast to get on track with the vision for this: Neural Lace Podcast Season 2 Episode 1 NeuroTechX and OpenEIT https://youtu.be/aexQwTpOwYc with Jean Rintoul

New! If you really want to be up to date please also watch the Neural Lace Podcast S2 E2 with Jules Urbach https://youtu.be/yMsaNsqzjFQ

Our objective is to merge Brain Machine Interfaces with WebXR, AR VR headsets, Machine Learning (Deep Learning Artificial Intelligence), Blockchain and more. To create new core medical technologies.

Our upcoming goals include
1. Update the WebVR visuals to make it more interesting, and to incorporate the new FFT data so that we are visualizing Alpha, Beta, Theta, Delta, Gamma waves. Also build a 3D Spectrogram in VR.

2. Figure out how to capture the time stamped user data (ie the user is looking at Cube3 at 9:05:47pm) and the time stamped EEG data from the VR headset, send it into a free cloud based database (like mysql), and use that to train a neural network (like tensorflow or ptorch or we could use baidu ez dl)

3. Broadcast our EEG server & html page to the open web so we are not using local hosts.

4. Migrate a version of the EEG server & html to the Raspberry Pi Zero W. and the Mac Mini

5. Secure the medical data (EEG) on the blockchain with Kara app by OasisLabs https://medium.com/oasislabs

Previous Progress: We made significant progress at the July 29th, 2018 meetup: We were able to cause voltages from the skin to move objects in WebVR. https://www.facebook.com/worksalt/videos/2332211350138832/

Be excellent to each other: Assume everyone else could be more knowledgeable about WebXR or 3D technology than you are. Never assume that women or other minorities or anyone else knows less than you about any topic! Assume you are among the best and brightest in the world, because the best and brightest in the world actually do come to the Noisebridge Hackerspace, NeurotechSF meetups, and SF VR meetups regularly.

Getting here: https://www.noisebridge.net/wiki/Getting_Here

Other links including the Github and our online groups: https://medium.com/@vrma/list-of-links-from-neurotech-sf-vr-on-8-31-2018-7a80cfd3901b

In order to attend, please register and pay here: https://asv-noam-wasserman-fireside.eventbrite.com/?aff=IDEATOIPO&afu=3951017871

Our meetup members get 10% OFF!

Use promo code: IDEA-TO-IPO

***DO NOT RSVP ON OUR MEETUP SITE.***

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
About the Guest Speaker

Noam Wasserman is the Jorge Paulo and Susanna Lemann Chair in Entrepreneurship and the founding director of the Founder Central initiative at the University of Southern California. Before returning home to Los Angeles, he was a professor at Harvard Business School for 13 years. His book, The Founder’s Dilemmas: Anticipating and Avoiding the Pitfalls That Can Sink a Startup, was an Amazon #1 bestseller in Management, has spent more than half a decade on the Strategy bestseller list.

For more than a decade, his research has focused on founders’ early decisions that can make or break the startup and its team. At HBS, he developed and teaches an MBA elective, “Founders’ Dilemmas,” for which he was awarded the HBS Faculty Teaching Award and the Academy of Management’s 2010 Innovation in Pedagogy Award. In 2011, the course was also named one of the top entrepreneurship courses in the country by Inc. magazine. His book, The Founder’s Dilemmas: Anticipating and Avoiding the Pitfalls That Can Sink a Startup, was published in March by Princeton University Press. Both The Founder’s Dilemmas (the book) and Founders’ Dilemmas (the course) provide a roadmap for founders about the most common pitfalls they will face. The book and course integrate Noam’s research results, quantitative data collected over the last decade from 10,000 founders, case studies, and conceptual frameworks. Noam’s second book is Life is a Startup: What Founders Can Teach Us about Making Choices and Managing Change (Stanford University Press, fall 2018).

About the Book--Founder’s Dilemmas. ( A must-read for every startup entrepreneur.) --------------------------------------------------------------------------
Often downplayed in the excitement of starting up a new business venture is one of the most important decisions entrepreneurs will face: should they go it alone, or bring in co-founders, hires, and investors to help build the business? More than just financial rewards are at stake. Friendships and relationships can suffer. Bad decisions at the inception of a promising venture lay the foundations for its eventual ruin. The Founder's Dilemmas is the first book to examine the early decisions by entrepreneurs that can make or break a startup and its team. This book is thought of by many as the proverbial "Startup Bible" and his most recent book, "Life is a Startup", is sure to be equally as impactful.

Don't miss this rare, must see, Fireside Chat"UNLEASHED" with Noam Wasserman this October!

Learn more and get tickets here: https://asv-noam-wasserman-fireside.eventbrite.com/?aff=IDEATOIPO&afu=3951017871
