name: Volunteering- What can, what should we do- for what community?
description:
Life is an everlong search for happiness and we all long to find something - anything - to give our lives joy and meaning. While we are individuals with different wants and needs, research suggests that volunteering is an activity that everyone can benefit from to live a more meaningful life. Back in 2016, Daryl Van Tongeren and his colleagues sought to examine this relationship in an article for The Journal of Positive Psychology. In a preliminary study, the researchers asked over 400 participants to report on how frequently they engage in different altruistic behaviors (such as volunteering) and how meaningful their life feels. Participants who were more altruistic reported a greater sense of purpose and meaning in their lives.

The importance of service to the wellbeing of our soul makes sense, especially in the United States. Americans embody a strong culture of individualism and achievement that we often get lost in our own worlds, losing perspective about the bigger picture of life. With volunteering, it releases us from a bondage of individualism we have formed that fosters a state of mind that encourages deeper relationships with others and ourselves.

Is volunteering a key to a more meaningful life? We discuss the different ways volunteering can affect us from different perspectives, whether it be individually, in relation to others, or communal.

Volunteering - Individual Need
● Why are people drawn to volunteering? What are the benefits of it?
● When you volunteer, what are you looking to get from it?
● Do you think volunteering is necessary for individual well-being? If so, in what ways?
● How do you prioritize what volunteer organization gets your time and money, given that there are so many out there?
● What makes the difference between a satisfying volunteering opportunity and a non-satisfying one?
● What does satisfaction look like after volunteering?
● Can we find satisfaction in volunteering that can’t be found in other activities?
● How important is the satisfaction you get in volunteering to living a meaningful life?

Volunteering - Relationships with Others
● Does volunteering provide an opportunity to build relationships?
● How is relationship building through volunteering different than traditional methods of relationship building (i.e. bars, social clubs, sports teams)?
● Does volunteering build the capacity to create more meaningful relationships?
● Does volunteering enforce power dynamics between people who volunteer and people who receive services of volunteer organizations?
● How is charity and volunteering different? What are the implications between the person giving to the person receiving?

Volunteering - Building a Community
● Does volunteering reinforce or dismantle the strong culture of individualism in the United States?
● Is volunteering particularly important to the LGBT community?
● What can be achieved through volunteering that can’t be achieved through paid work?
● Is volunteering necessary to create a strong community?
● What is the difference between volunteering and charity? In outcomes for the provider and recipient? Is one better than the other?
● What are the benefits or drawbacks to cultures that rely on volunteering for services vs. those that rely on government or families?

name: Pismo Beach Weekend Adventure with ATVs!
description:
Ready for an awesome day to play in the sand with some toys? Come down and join us at Pismo Beach (Oceano State Park) to play in the sand and hang out on the beach!

We will meet on Friday at the Gilroy Walmart Parking lot and from there head down to Pismo which should arrive just around sunset. You have to air down your tires to drive on the sand, it's about a mile drive from that point. When we get to the main camping area, we will attempt to drive a bit up the hill to get behind the main beach traffic. Depending on how much time, we will set a bonfire and relax.

Saturday will be a full day of playing with the toys! If you don't have your own, there are rental options. Just google "Pismo Beach ATV Rentals" and you will get results. Here is one company you can start with if you like:

https://pismoatvrentals.com/

Bring your own ride if you have one. Rentals typically cost ~$160 for 6 hours of riding. I advise to reserve online as walk in pricing could be more. If you want to split the cost with others you are free to do so but you will want to coordinate that in the discussion. If you have your own quad, there is a chance I might have space for one on a trailer. Message me to discuss.

Saturday night will be another bonfire. Dinner will be what you bring. I will have a camper with a stove and a microwave available for anyone wanting to heat up some food. Sunday morning we can play a little longer for those that wish before heading home.

Sleeping will be tent / RV / car / whatever you have.

If you only want to stay for the day on Saturday, that is okay but just note it is unlikely you would be able to find our group. There are so many people out there and we will be riding during the day so you may not be able to message me to ask directions.

For carpooling, I will have seats for 3 people in my F350 for those that are willing to split gas. First come first serve. If you want to caravan with your own ride your welcome to join us.

In regards to driving on the sand, the beach portion is hard-packed and you likely won't have a problem even with a small car (lot's of small cars are present). Once you turn in to the dunes, the sand gets more difficult to drive on. There are a LOT of people always ready to help give you a pull should you get stuck. I have a 2WD truck myself and managed fairly well.

There is a $20 RSVP fee to ensure that you are committed to going that is non-refundable. It also helps to cover the cost of Meetup and the time to plan / coordinate the event. If you are driving a vehicle, there is a $10 per night charge as well. Those in my vehicle will be covered. The $20 does NOT cover the cost of renting an ATV.

name: Happy Isles (Yosemite Valley) to Cloud’s Rest Backpacking
description:
Have room for 1, maybe 2, in the car for this three night backpacking trip. Departing SF.

Current itinerary (open to some changes):
Sunday drive to Yosemite and pickup Wilderness backpacking permit by 3:30 pm. Hike to Little Yosemite Valley (3.8 miles via JMT or 4.7 miles via Mist Trail). Camp at Little Yosemite Valley.

Mon approx 6 mile hike to Cloud’s Rest. Camp somewhere near there.

Tues either hike all the way back to the car and camp at the backpackers campsite (10-11 miles, a ton of downhill so hiking poles suggested) or to Little Yosemite Valley again.

Wed either hike to the car or do a short day hike or enjoy the Valley. Depart for SF by 9:30 am.

We have two large bear canisters which should be sufficient for up to 4 of us. You must be a moderately experienced backpacker and be comfortable with a minimum of 7 miles per day. Strenuous elevation gain to Cloud’s Rest with the same strenuous downhill.

name: BOTH Sequoia and Kings Canyon NPs in One Perfect Backpacking/Dayhiking Trip
description:
Good afternoon, "Last-Minute Backpackers!”

I have finalized my Sequoia and Kings Canyon (SEKI) trip (where we will be both backpackers AND “marginal tourists”).

It will be the FIVE DAY/FOUR NIGHT trip now beginning (very early) on Oct 18th through the 22nd.

Not heavy backpacking: two non-consecutive backcountry evenings and two in NP campgrounds as staging points for two non-consecutive days' hiking among the Sequoias.

I can drive one more of you to and from (depending, of course, on where you live), but, please know I have one attendee in my Prius already whom I am picking up at 6-30-ish already and he lives in the East Bay...

Here is the FIVE DAY/FOUR NIGHT itinerary:

DAY ONE, 10/18/18:

Leave the Bay area no later than 6:30 am. (Therefore, if you are traveling with me, I will schedule to pick you up earlier than this.) Directions to Grant Grove Kings Canyon Visitor Center via the Big Stump Entrance on Highway 180: https://www.nps.gov/seki/planyourvisit/directions.htm.

Meet at the Grant Grove Kings Canyon Visitor Center no later than 1:00. I will secure our Wilderness Permit.

Arrive at the Redwood Saddle Trailhead to embark on the Redwood Canyon/Hart Meadow Trail. Directions: From Grant Grove drive 5 miles south on the Generals Highway, turn right at Quail Flat onto a rough dirt road. Continue for 1.5 miles-ish to Redwood Saddle and follow the left fork to the parking area.

Backpack the 4.5 mile Hart Tree and Fallen Goliath Loop.

Night One's stay will be at the confluence of the three trails (Redwood Canyon, Hart Meadow, Sugar Bowl trails) along Redwood Creek.

DAY TWO, 10/19/18:

Leave the Redwood Canyon campsite and backpack to the Redwood Saddle Trailhead via the Redwood Canyon Trail.

Drive to Lodgepole Campground in Lodgepole Village. We will exit from the Redwood Canyon Trailhead no later than 11:00. At Lodgepole, we will set up camp for TWO NIGHTS. Directions to Lodgepole Campground: Return to General’s Highway and turn east. Continue until you reach the Lodgepole Village turnoff. Turn left and drive to the campground.

Drive to Grant Grove to dayhike among the giant Sequoias, including the General Grant Tree, the second (or third) largest tree in the world.

Return to Lodgepole Campground in Lodgepole Village.

Night Two's stay in Lodgepole Campground. There are flush toilets and showers(!) on site.

DAY THREE, 10/20/18:

Drive to the Wolverton parking area to begin a full day of dayhiking (therefore, please bring a daypack!) from the General Sherman Tree through the Giant Forest through Crescent Meadow to Tharp's Log to Moro Rock. Then, we will hike back to our car at Wolverton.

Night Three's stay will be in Lodgepole Campground, as well.

DAY FOUR, 10/21/22:

We will drive to the Wolverton parking area to begin our last leg, a backpacking hike up the Lakes Trail. Before we embark, I will secure the self-serve Wilderness Permit at the Lodgepole Visitor Center before leaving.

Night Four's stay will be at either Emerald Lake or Pear Lake.

DAY FIVE, 10/22/18:

We will backpack to the Wolverton parking area to begin our drive back to the Bay Area.

Though I am unsure, I believe we can shower, if wanted, at the Lodgepole Campground (NO PROMISES, though!).

PLEASE KEEP IN MIND:

1) Participation in this trip affirms you have read, understood, and agreed to the liability statement in the 'Pages’ section of Meetup’s Last-Minute Backpackers website (see: https://www.meetup.com/Last-Minute-Backpackers/about/).

2) SEKI charges $30 for entry that I did not cover. If you are traveling separately, please bring $30 for a seven-day pass.

3) There is a $22/night fee per camp space that I did not cover. We will divide the total by the number of campers.

4) There are no gas stations within the park: GAS UP!

5) Remember: There is no food or supplies provided. Bring sufficient food, supplies, water purification, warm clothing and sleeping gear.

6) It may snow: Bring snow chains.

Contact me soon!

Thanks much!

name: Backpack to Chewing Gum Lake
description:
It's 3.8 miles from Crabtree TH to Chewing Gum lake. There is 1800ft elevation gain in the first 2.6 miles. I was at the lake 2 years ago and it's a pretty little lake. That time we hiked in from Gianelli TH. That trail is a little longer and the access road is long and rough.

Being late in the season this trip is very weather dependent. If the forecast is for rain we'll postpone a week or even two.

I will be camping at the TH Friday night, you are welcome to join me.

This is the trail we will be hiking;
https://caltopo.com/m/R70G

State law requires everyone to have a fire permit to use a camp stove in the wilderness. Please get your camp stove fire permit here;
https://caltopo.com/m/R70G

Emigrant Wilderness allows your food to be stored in canisters, properly hung and/or Ursack bags.

Failure to answer the RSVP question is grounds for being removed from the trip.

Be sure to include a note which trip you are paying for!
http://www.paypal.me/backpackingwithjeff/20
or $20 to
http://www.venmo.com/Jeff-Weston-1

As always if you have any questions don't hesitate to ask.

name: Beginner Backpacking - Introductory Class
description:
For anyone that is really wanting to try backpacking in 2018 but doesn't know where to begin, here is your chance! I offer these introductory courses where I will do a casual overview of all things backpacking! This is a three hour long informal course with the idea that you will have all of the knowledge necessary for your first overnight trip. 

We will cover the following:

• Backpacking Gear: Packs, Tents, Sleeping Bags, Sleeping Pads, Stoves, etc...

• What to buy, what to rent (and where)

• Clothes / Footwear

• Trip Planning, Routes, Maps, GPS 

• Basic Safety / Survival Skills

• Picking a Campsite 

• Trail Etiquete 

• Bathroom Survival Tips 

• Food Ideas & Trail Cooking

The RSVP fee covers my time, plus refreshments and also ensures your commitment to attending. This course is the first of a three part series of courses for getting started in backpacking. Anyone who attends this class session, will receive 50% off of two follow on courses: My First 1 Night Backpacking Trip and my 3 night My First Multi-Day Backpacking Trip trips that I will be hosting in 2018. 

To ensure we get full attendance, this event will be cross posted with Christian Camping & Backpacking Meetup Group.

name: Half Moon Bay Beach Camping
description:
Here is a great chance to stay at one of the nicest group campsites in the Bay Area right near the beach at Half Moon Bay! This will be our Spring Social / Mixer to meet other like minded car camping and backpacking enthusiasts. We can discuss trip ideas for Summer 2018, talk trail, eat food and enjoy the beach. 

I have reserved the Sweetwood Group Camp site for three nights (Wednesday to Saturday). Here is a brief description: Sweetwood Group Camp offers a fire pit, picnic benches, running water, and toilets (of the non-flush variety). These amenities are more than adequate for a short weekend outing. The camp site is far from remote, so if you require anything, a number of stores and restaurants are but a short drive away.

Note!!! There is limited parking available and it will be set aside first for people who will be staying in a small Camper / Van / RV / Tear Drop. If you are Tent Camping, you can offload your gear but will have to park a short distance away in one of the parking lots for vehicles. Additional Parking fees are not covered in your reservation. Any spaces not taken up by vehicle campers will be given to tent campers on a first come first serve basis.

Early-bird Reservations: If you RSVP before 31 December, your Fee will be $50.00 per adult and $25.00 per child. Anything after that it will be $60.00 per adult but still $25.00 per child.

Optional - Children's Camping Adventure: Saturday to Sunday we will be having a fun camping adventure geared just for the young ones! If you have kids or grandkids you would like to take on this adventure, check out this event at our Bay Area Parents & Kids Social Club Meetup group.

You can come for all three nights or just for one or two nights but the RSVP fee is the same. Because this even is for Wednesday to Saturday, I'm posting this event out far in advance so you can coordinate your work schedule if necessary.

name: Backpacking Social & Gear Swap
description:
Let's kick off the summer with a Last Minute Backpacker social and gear swap! This will give us a chance to meet new friends, see old ones and make plans for future backpacking adventures this upcoming season!

Did you just upgrade to the latest feather weight backup and don't know what to do with your old but good backpack? Bring that older (but still usable) gear with you and let others take a look and possibly get a good deal! We will attempt a gear swap to allow people to sell / exchange their unwanted gear to others looking to either get into backpacking or wanting to upgrade when on a tight budget. 

Location: Robert & Evelyn's  in Gilroy

Food: We will provide home made Street Tacos, chips, sodas and some sides. If you wish to bring a side dish of some sort to contribute you are more than welcome to do so.

RSVP Fee: A minimal $7 fee is charged to help purchase the food for the event and to ensure you are committed to attending.

What to Bring: Sun Screen, Water, Camp Chair (seating will be limited), Food to Share (Optional), 

Gear Swap: Any camping or backpacking gear you are interested in letting go of for free or to sell at a fair price please bring it for a first attempted gear swap. This gear swap idea is an experiment, not certain how many people might bring gear or how many might be interested in buying. I figure it is worth a try to see if we might try this again next year.

name: SFJS: RxJS, Schedulers and More
description:
We're working on recruiting some great speakers. Message the organizers if you have an idea for a talk.

🏢 Our hosts: PubNub helps you launch your app fast with realtime APIs and global messaging infrastructure.
ℹ Use cases: https://www.pubnub.com/solutions/
ℹ JS SDK: https://www.pubnub.com/docs/web-javascript/pubnub-javascript-sdk

🍕 Snacks & 🥤Drinks, 6pm-6:30pm: Sponsored by IBM Developers
Check out upcoming IBM Developers Bay Area events on JavaScript, Data Science, Machine Learning and more: https://www.meetup.com/IBM-Developer-SF-Bay-Area-Meetup

🤖 Upcoming IBM Meetup: Continuously Improve your Watson Bot https://www.meetup.com/IBM-Developer-SF-Bay-Area-Meetup/events/255061389/

🎙 Speaker #1, 6:30pm: Gerard Sans http://twitter.com/gerardsans
"Bending Time with Schedulers and RxJS 6"
Observables have been very popular because of their many qualities: asynchronous processing, composition, performance, powerful operators. But usually there's a less covered feature that lies beneath. That is: Schedulers. In this talk we are going to cover Schedulers in depth, going from the basic APIs to more obscure features to bend time to our will!

🎙 Speaker #2, 7:00pm: TBD

🤩 15 Seconds of Fame, 7:30pm: Want to share your idea with the group? Now is your time! You get 15 seconds.

🍻 Networking, 7:30pm-8:30pm

🕴 Go home, 8:30pm

name: Vicente Amigo - Flamenco - SFJazz - Oct. 11-14
description:
Tickets:
https://www.sfjazz.org/tickets/productions/vicente-amigo-1819/
4 concerts, October 11, 12, 13, 14
Crowned by the late maestro Paco de Lucía as the next great flamenco star, Spanish guitarist Vicente Amigo has more than lived up to his promise. Following in de Lucía’s footsteps, he’s forged musical ties with artists around the world, from Sting to Brazilian masters Milton Nascimento and Eliane Elias to jazz guitar innovators including John McLaughlin and Al Di Meola. Born outside of Seville and raised in Córdoba, Amigo began working professionally as a teen, and in 1993, the same year he released his debut album, he was awarded Best Flamenco Guitarist by Guitar Player magazine.

By the time Amigo made his Bay Area debut in 2002, the guitarist’s career was in rapid ascent on the heels of his fourth album, City of Ideas, which had won the 2001 Latin GRAMMY as Best Flamenco Album. Following the imaginative blend of Spanish and Celtic influences on 2013’s Tierra, Amigo returns to a pure expression of the flamenco tradition with his new Sony Legacy release Memoria de los Sentidos (Memory of the Senses). The guitarist’s live performances feature pyrotechnic virtuosity, charisma and copious quantities of that intangible quality of Iberian music called duende, which Amigo explains simply: “If you hurt when you hear it, then it’s duende.”

name: Lutenist Richard Savino, Palo Alto, Berkeley, SF, Oct. 12-14
description:
information: http://sfems.org/?page_id=13456

El Mundo
Kingdoms of Castile

Directed by world-renowned guitarist and lutenist Richard Savino, El Mundo will take listeners on a musical journey from Castilian courts and cathedrals to Spanish-influenced Italian cities like Naples and on to the viceroyalties of Peru, Mexico, and Guatemala, where classical tradition blended with indigenous dances to create a unique Hispanic style that still exists today.

The villancico is a specialty of El Mundo, and this concert will feature a rich selection from their recent, GRAMMY© nominated CD. The villancico, one of music’s most resilient and popular vocal genres, originally developed in the 15th century and evolved through the 17th & 18th centuries to become the dominant vocal genre throughout Spain and Latin America. This same period saw the Spanish colonies of Central and South America blossom into well-springs of cultural sophistication. Latin American cathedrals and courtly life demanded a varied and active musical scene. Often, the indigenous populations were drawn into the arts and participated in their production. The musical result was a style that even in sacred compositions bears the imprint of folk music, a delightful intersection of elegance and simplicity. The use of guitars and percussion, coupled with dance rhythms and the occasional use of native languages, demonstrate a close relationship between European and Indigenous cultures.

EL MUNDO: Richard Savino, Director; Jennifer Ellis Kampani, soprano; Adam LaMotte and Lisa Grodin, violins; Aaron Westman, viola; William Skeen, cello; Richard Savino, guitars

name: SF Mandolin Orchestra: "Grand Tour" (Palo Alto)
description:
Three hundred years ago European men and women of means took “The Grand Tour” of the continent in search of art, culture, and learning.

And now YOU can take a musical “Grand Tour” with the SF Mandolin Orchestra. Our fall program features orchestral works from Germany, Spain, Italy, and other countries representing the heart of European culture. Our musical journey will include:

* Violin Concerto in A Minor by J.S. Bach, featuring our music director Achille Bocus as mandolin soloist
* Notturno in Sol by Italian composer Giuseppe Martucci
* March from the opera Fidelio by Ludwig van Beethoven
* Excerpts from Joaquín Rodrigo’s guitar concerto Fantasia Para un Gentilhombre, featuring soloist Nicholas Martin
…and much more.

Concerts are family-friendly. Admission is $20 general, $15 student/senior, and free for children 12 and under. Tickets may be purchased at the door, or at our ticketing site: http://www.brownpapertickets.com/producer/597471

name: San Francisco Conservatory of Music Community Guitar Orchestra
description:
• What we'll do
The San Francisco Conservatory of Music Adult Extension Division is creating a Community Guitar Orchestra. It will bring together Bay Area guitar enthusiasts to rehearse and perform a wide range of musical styles from the Renaissance, Baroque, Classical, Romantic, and Modern periods. Under the direction of guitarist Scott Cmiel, students rehearse in a collaborative environment to improve their musicianship, technique, and reading skills. A placement assessment is required for participation.

Placement is required to enable the director to create ensembles where performers will feel excited and enthusiastic about the music they are playing. There is no need to be a virtuoso - good tone, good memory, and enthusiastic attitude are all that’s required.

PLACEMENT REQUIREMENTS

Performance of a solo work which demonstrates your ability
Two-octave scale using any left hand fingering you like and played rest stroke with i-m alternation
A pima arpeggio and a pami arpeggio using common chords or open strings

Placement can be done via video recording or in person. Please send video recordings to Justin Sun, Program Manager for the Adult Extension Division, at [masked]. It is recommended that the video recording be sent via Google Drive, Dropbox, Youtube, or similar video hosting services.

Placement can also be scheduled in person with Scott Cmiel.
Please contact Justin Sun at [masked] to schedule an in person placement.

name: Gear, Knots & Anchors class
Multipitch Trad Following and Leading skills class
Satyajit Ray's "The Goddess (Devi)"
description:
Join us Sunday October 21 at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art for a screening of Indian director Satyajit Ray's classic film, The Goddess. soundtrack.

“Satyajit Ray’s dreamily sensual, ironic film about Indian superstitiousness was originally banned from export until Nehru interceded. The story, about a wealthy man who convinces his son’s bride that she is an incarnation of the goddess Kali, has startling Freudian undertones. Ray’s feeling for the intoxicating beauty within the disintegrating way of life of the nineteenth-century landowning class makes this one of the rare, honest films about decadence...Ray creates an atmosphere that intoxicates us as well; the household is so rich and the rich people so overripe....And perhaps because of the camera work, which seems to derive from some of the best traditions of the silent screen and the ’30s, perhaps because of the Indian faces themselves, the eyes have depths — and a disturbing look of helplessness — that we are unused to. It’s almost as if these people were isolated from us and each other by their eyes....Sharmila Tagore (Tagore’s great-granddaughter), 14 when she played Apu’s bride, is the 17-year-old goddess; she is exquisite, perfect in both these roles.” — The New Yorker

Tickets are $12 general.

https://www.sfmoma.org/event/goddess-devi/

6:30 Purchase film tickets (Note: Museum admission is not necessary) and take our seats in the Phyllis Watts Theater. The film starts at 7:00.

8:30 After the program we will meet for conversation at Ghirardelli Ice Cream & Chocolate Shop (2 New Montgomery St.).

name: Free Screening: The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari, with Live Piano!
description:
This Halloween, come hear acclaimed pianist Frederick Hodges accompany San Francisco Public Library's free screening of the classic silent horror film, The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari. Famous for its Expressionist sets, its bizarre plot twists, and its paranoid psychological atmosphere, Caligari presents an unsettling story about a mysterious hypnotist, his patient, and a series of violent murders.

Don't miss this exciting evening of film and live music!

Director Robert Wiene. In German with English subtitles. Live piano accompaniment by Frederick Hodges. 75 minutes.

Presented by SFPL’s General Collections & Humanities Center together with the Art, Music, & Recreation Center.

More info: https://sfpl.org/index.php?pg=1033634001

name: Community Manager Productivity Hacks: A Panel Discussion at Asana
description:
The art and science of scaling communities has its tricks and tools that help things grow without breaking down. In our October meetup, we will host a panel discussion, at Asana, on how to best use productivity tools to manage and scale your community.

About the Panelists:

Katie Andresen is part of the Community team at Square where she focuses on seller engagement. She’s also an accredited mediator, working with SF Community Boards, and volunteers with the Phenomenal Woman Action Campaign. Previously, Katie worked in public policy and civic tech.

Twitter: @Square
Web: https://squareup.com/
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/katieandresen/

Alexis Luscutoff is a community manager at Dropbox with a focus on fostering customer connection and engagement. She formerly led community at Asana, having launched Asana's community forum and the company's first online champion program. Alexis has a background in marketing and earned her MA in Communication from Stanford University. In addition to her work in community, Alexis is a coactive life coach with a sub-specialty in how body language impacts communication.

Twitter: @alexisluscutoff
Web: https://dropbox.com
Linkedin: https://www.linkedin.com/in/alexisluscutoff/

Kyle ("mos") Redington is a community manager currently employed with Twitch. As a painter and creator, he came from the community developing content alongside the creators that he currently supports. The programs that he runs, including the TwitchCon Cosplay Contest and Artist Alley, support the non-gaming creators on Twitch. He also runs the community meetup program, supporting local gatherings of passionate Twitch users together.

All Social Media: @monkeyonstrike @Twitch
Web: twitch.tv
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/twitch-tv/

Aaron Weiss is a Community Manager at Autodesk. Aaron helps manage a global, product support-focused community of the world’s best architects, engineers, designers. He empowers users to help other users master highly complex and technical softwares (but might not know how to use said softwares himself). He also has a background in growing and engaging a young community at MindSumo and managing a staff of technology & culture focused writers at Thelma.com. In his free time you can catch him in SF biking up and down hills, eating burritos, or playing basketball in Dolores park.
Twitter: @aarontw
Web: Autodesk.com
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/aarontaylorweiss/

Joshua Zerkel is Head of Global Community at Asana, where he’s responsible for growing and engaging the Asana community around the world. He's also a Certified Professional Organizer® and has spent over a decade helping people and businesses get more organized and increase their productivity. Before joining Asana, Josh was Director of Global Customer Education and Community at Evernote.

Twitter: @joshuazerkel
Web: asana.com
LinkedIn: linkedin.com/in/joshuazerkel
Twitter: @asana
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/asana

Moderated by Bill Johnston of Structure3C
Bill is an experienced online community-builder with a primary focus of developing large-scale online communities. He designed and launched TechRepublic.com, quickly growing to 2mm members globally. Bill has held senior positions with Autodesk and Dell, where he developed and grew highly engaged online communities and high-functioning community teams.

His new firm, Structure3C, focuses on designing modern communities and networked customer experiences, working with leading brands like Salesforce, IBM, Intuit and AARP. You can find out more by visiting blog.structure3c.com.

description:
TGSF usually has an End of Month dinner/gathering on the last Thursday of each month, except:

March, we attend TDoV (Transgender Day of Visibility) - http://TDoV.org/
June, we attend Trans March - http://TransMarch.org/
November 20, we attend TDoR (Transgender Day of Remembrance) - http://TDoRSF.org/
December, we'll meet before the traditional winter holidays

If another trans-related event is important to support, it will be substituted for that month's gathering.

Always check the calendar for the latest information: http://tgsf.org/calendar/.

We try to keep the Meetup http://www.meetup.com/TGSF-Transgender-San-Francisco/ , and Facebook https://www.facebook.com/GenderSF/ pages up to date, but the best way to contact us is through email.

Volunteers are always needed!

name: Libertarian Party of San Francisco monthly meeting and social!
description:
The Libertarian Party of San Francisco (http://www.LPSF.org) holds our regular monthly meetings on the 2nd Saturday each month, from 3-5pm, followed by a social.

Everyone is welcome to come and be part of the discussion, however in order to vote on party business you must be registered to vote as a Libertarian (http://www.sos.ca.gov/elections/elections_vr.htm) if eligible, and become an LP member by completing a membership form (http://lpsf.org/become-a-member). Sometimes our meetings include a guest speaker. After the meetings, we will typically stick around for a couple hours for a social. We will bring some light food and drinks usually pick up a pizza or two after the meeting is over. Please feel free to bring whatever you like to share! You're welcome to come for just the social, just the meeting, or both. You can always check meeting details, or find out the latest LPSF news and happenings, on our Libertarian Party of San Francisco website (http://www.LPSF.org). Thanks for your support of freedom, and on behalf of our local chair Nick Smith and the rest of our group, we look forward to meeting you!

– Starchild, LPSF Outreach Director and Meetup Group organizer

name: The Gold Standard: History, Theory, and Fallacies
description:
**This event is hosted by our friends at Golden Gate Liberty r3volution**

The gold standard has plenty of advocates and even more critics. But what exactly is the gold standard? Is it a singular monetary system or have multiple versions of the gold standard operated in different countries at different times throughout history? What are the gold standard's virtues and what are the challenges and objections to returning to gold-based money?

Chris Silber's second and last monetary economics lecture of 2018 integrates a brief history of the gold standard with the theoretical concepts that govern its operation including the market-driven monetary base, gold's role in monetary aggregates, Gresham's Law, and inflation/deflation. The talk will conclude with a list of fallacies and objections cited by enemies and even friends of gold against replacing today's dominant fiat monetary systems with a gold standard.

Chris Silber is a frequent attendee of GGLR and Free Exchange meetings and has previously presented on monetary history, business cycles, and the Great Depression.

description: As mentioned in the group description, please bring either: a dessert, and appetizer, some beer / wine, or $15 to help spread the costs. Home cooked food a plus! name: Waterdeep: Dragon Heist! - Dungeons and Dragons (5e) AL
description:
(Note: This is an ongoing group that does various D&D adventures following official rules. RSVP list will be adjusted during ongoing series to prefer consistent players, but new players are welcome as space allows.)

Come venture into adventure by meeting a group of heroes in a tavern this Monday night! The game will be Dungeons and Dragons 5th Edition and run according to Adventurer's League rules:

Basic Player Information for AL:

https://www.dmsguild.com/product/208178/DD-Adventurers-League-Player--DM-Pack?filters=45470_0_0_0_0_0_0_0

http://dnd.wizards.com/playevents/organized-play

This is a long term D&D group now starting the first in a series of related adventures set in the sprawling coastal city of Waterdeep, located on the Sword Coast (The "Forgotten Realms" setting). We are now doing the "Dragon Heist" hardcover adventure, possibly to be interspersed with shorter, related adventures.

New players welcome, please message the event host through meetup if you have any questions. Anyone on the waitlist is welcome to attend to observe, or in the event someone who has signed up doesn't show. First priority is given to consistent previous attendees, followed by new players on a first-come, first served basis. Anyone who signs up but does not show up without messaging the host, or leaving a comment (before, during, or shortly after the meetup) may be bumped to the waitlist to make room for others. Please send any and all questions to the event host.

name: Waterdeep Wednesdays (5e)
description:
Potentially non-recurring spots available for Waterdeep: Dragon Heist, for those looking for a one-shot-esque fix.

For a more regular game, check out the new group forming:
https://www.meetup.com/d204life/events/qjfphqyxnbnb/

Please note the venue has a $5/person table fee, typically charged upon ordering food/drink.

name: Kai'ieta Archipelago (5e Homebrew Setting)
description:
I am starting a 5e Homebrew Campaign on Wednesday Nights at the Game Parlor given that the current game there has had to turn some people away due to the amount of interest.

The game will be set in my homebrew world of Rhulea in the Kai'ieta Archipelago, the homeland of Kenku and Tortles. It is however a very diverse place, where almost every race can be found. The game will run as a semi-sandbox game, with the opportunity to explore various events around the islands and to leave the archipelago entirely and venture into the rest of Rhulea later on.

Half of the first game will be a session 0 where I explain my world a little as people build level 4 characters. An NPC or two from your backstory (friendly or not) to ground your characters in the world would be nice, but is not necessary.

I allow these character classes and races, but if there is a homebrew you want to try out, message me. So long as it isn’t crazy broken or hard to understand, I will probably allow it.

https://drive.google.com/open?id=1CarYJWdUovraH6Hh8b1QXa4siu19xJZs

Are you a female player? Have you ever experienced being the only woman at the table in a D&D game? My girlfriend has. She would really love if that wasn’t the case for this game. A couple of women have shown when there have been openings in the past, but almost never at the same time. Hopefully we can change that. I’m going to reserve a couple spots for women, so even if this fills up, feel free to message me.

name: Waterdeep: Dragon Heist - Game Session #4
description:
Bold knights dare the crypts of dead monarchs, seeking glory and treasure. Insolent rogues prowl the dank alleyways of ancient cities, plotting their next exploit. Devout clerics wield mace and spell, questing against the terrifying powers that threaten the land. Cunning wizards plunder the ruins of fallen empires, delving fearlessly into secrets too dark for the light of day. Dragons, giants, black-hearted villains, demons, savage hordes, and unimaginable abominations lurk in horrible dungeons, endless caverns, ruined cities, and the vast wild places of the world, thirsting for the blood of heroes.

This is the land of Faerûn, a continent of heart-stopping beauty and ages-old evil. It is your land to shape, to guide, to defend, to conquer, or to rule. It is a land trod by noble heroes and unredeemable villains, a great and terrible company to which you and your fellows now belong.

Across Faerûn, the name “Waterdeep” evokes feelings of wonder, awe, and envy. Although it is not the largest city in the Realms, the City of Splendors is undoubtedly the most famous and most cosmopolitan metropolis on the continent of Faerûn. Having grown rich on a steady diet of trade and industry, this crossroads city combines the best aspects of many cultures into a marvelous shining jewel. Waterdeep’s cultural patrimony is all of Faerûn, and its inhabitants are much richer for it.

Waterdeep is home to haughty nobles, diligent craftsmen, scheming merchants, daring sailors, and bold adventurers of every stripe. It has always been a center of wealth and influence where those who dream of power, riches, or artistic fulfillment can come to to realize their aspirations.

It is also a city of fearsome dungeons.

Undermountain and the Dungeon of the Crypt promise untold riches and deadly monsters to those who dare their depths. Skullport, the Port of Shadow, beckons to those who seek illicit goods and dark dearlings. Ancient feuds divide Waterdeep’s guilds and noble houses, and many factions seek to topple the secretive Lords of Waterdeep. The Arcane Brotherhood of neighboring Luskan seeks to weaken its hated rival to the south, while the Red Wizards of Thay hope to dominate Waterdeep’s markets. The churches of Selûne and Shar use the City of Splendors as a battlefield in their eternal war, while countless mercenary groups come to the city to spend their hard-won earnings. The Shadow Thieves of Amn plot to overthrow the Lords who once drove them out of the city. Spies and mercenaries such as the Knights of the Shield and the Kraken Society spread rumors and steal closely held secrets, while agents of Skullport’s Iron Ring prowl for slaves to abduct into the depths. All the while, the secretive Lords of Waterdeep strive to preserve the city’s tolerant spirit, wise rule, and powerful magical tradition.

Little do you know that the events that have yet to unfold will bring an unlikely, disparate group of individuals together for the first time. You and the others are given the power to become heroes of the Sword Coast. But first, you must learn to understand yourself - and each other...

Waterdeep: Dragon Heist is an urban, Dungeons & Dragons 5th edition adventure for player character levels 1-5, held weekly in the Outer Richmond District of San Francisco.

This meetup is full and is not accepting additional players at this time.

name: CRISPR Workshop: The New Frontier of Biotechnology Innovation
description:
CRISPR Workshop: The New Frontier of Biotechnology Innovation

Join us at the InTeahouse for an exclusive CRISPR Workshop! This workshop focuses on the user interface of CRISPR technology and it is a platform for genome editing. Our workshop includes a lecture from an expert in the field of biotech. Experience a live walkthrough of the basic CRISPR cell engineering workflow. Please bring your laptop with you! Our experienced trainer will guide you through generating a knock-out knock-in construct using CRISPR-Cas9 and will work closely with you to help ensure a successful learning experience using these new methods. This is an exclusive event with limited seats available, Reserve your spot today!

Please sign in at the front desk on the 8th floor, and ask for InTeahouse

Background

By now, those who work in the biotech and life science industry have probably heard about the clustered and regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats. In short, they are the signatures of bacterial immune systems that scientists have hijacked into biological tools for editing genomes. The DNA-based instruction manuals from which all living things are built and maintained.
Since 2012, Largely due to its simplicity, efficiency, and low cost; CRISPR has become the genome-editing platform of choice for life scientists around the world. Often described as “molecular scissors,” the CRISPR system typically has two fundamental components: a strand of guide RNA (gRNA) and a CRISPR-associated endonuclease (e.g., Cas9). Together, they form a search-and-snip complex in which the gRNA takes on a hairpin shape.

• What to bring: Your Laptop
• Important to know: Please be sure to save your seat on Eventbrite
Link: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/crispr-workshop-the-new-frontier-of-biotechnology-innovation-tickets-50982888191

Agenda

5:[masked]pm: Registration & Networking

[masked]pm: Introduction

6.10- 7.40pm: Lecture

7.40- 8.10 pm: Q&A time

8.10- 8.30 pm: More Networking

name: FOUNDERS OPEN OFFICE
description:
Please register at the 8th floor reception, ask for InTeahouse.

Open office hours for founders and startups to ask any questions they have about getting started on their journey.

name: ⚽ Sunday Midday Drop-in Mini-Tournament! ⚽
description:
Sign up on our NEW APP! Its in the app store and is named Street Soccer USA Park! Sign up for Drop-ins, Manage your membership, and view our schedule!

Apple Store (https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/street-soccer-usa-park/id1238757573?ls=1&mt=8)

Android Store (https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=ie.zappy.fennec.streetsoccerusapark)

The coolest venue to play soccer, develop your skills, make new soccer friends, and give back to soccer programs for the underserved in San Francisco!

The Street Soccer USA Park (http://streetsoccerusapark.org/) offers Drop-In Mini-Tournaments Tuesday - Friday Nights & Saturday and Sunday Afternoons at 12pm. People that come include our regular members (not shown on MeetUp), people who work/live in the area that just show up (not shown on MeetUp), and people that hear about it through other channels, such as MeetUp (yourself).

How It Works: Come alone or come with your own 4v4 team (we recommend a sub or two since it is a fast game). We organize into our teams, helping the free agents join a team or form their own team, then play in an organized tournament where each team is guaranteed 3 games. The best 2 teams from the tournament then compete in the championship game for the Drop-In Mini-Tournament Trophy! Field is turf. Bring your shorts and soccer shoes. We will provide bibs. Games are always on, rain or shine.

About the Facility: The Street Soccer USA Park is a top of the line, small-sided outdoor soccer facility located at 200 Terry A Francois Blvd (in Lot A of the Giants Ballpark). It has two german-engineered 4v4 fields with high quality turf and non-toxic infill, electronically connected scoreboards, and an outdoor speaker system for music. Besides drop-in games, the Street Soccer USA Park offers 4v4 leagues, and youth programming.

Price: $15 per player (inquire about our memberships for a lower rate). Pay on site with cash or card.

Questions?

Call or email Austin at[masked] or [masked].

name: ⚽ Friday Night Drop-In Mini-Tournament! ⚽
description:
Sign up on our NEW APP! Its in the app store and is named Street Soccer USA Park! Sign up for Drop-ins, Manage your membership, and view our schedule!

Apple Store

Android Store

The coolest venue to play soccer, develop your skills, make new soccer friends, and give back to soccer programs for the underserved in San Francisco!

The Street Soccer USA Park offers Drop-In Mini-Tournaments Tuesday - Friday Nights & Saturday and Sunday Afternoons at 12pm. People that come include our regular members (not shown on MeetUp), people who work/live in the area that just show up (not shown on MeetUp), and people that hear about it through other channels, such as MeetUp (yourself).

How It Works: Come alone or come with your own 4v4 team (we recommend a sub or two since it is a fast game). We organize into our teams, helping the free agents join a team or form their own team, then play in an organized tournament where each team is guaranteed 3 games. The best 2 teams from the tournament then compete in the championship game for the Drop-In Mini-Tournament Trophy! Field is turf. Bring your shorts and soccer shoes. We will provide bibs. Games are always on, rain or shine.

About the Facility: The Street Soccer USA Park is a top of the line, small-sided outdoor soccer facility located at 200 Terry A Francois Blvd (in Lot A of the Giants Ballpark). It has two german-engineered 4v4 fields with high quality turf and non-toxic infill, electronically connected scoreboards, and an outdoor speaker system for music. Besides drop-in games, the Street Soccer USA Park offers 4v4 leagues, and youth programming.

Price: $15 per player (inquire about our memberships for a lower rate). Pay on site with cash or card.

Questions?

New Finnish Grammar by Diego Marani
description:
Winner of a ton of prizes and general acclaim in Italy, New Finnish Grammar is a story about memory and identity. Explores a favorite theme of mine: how does your perception of your own culture change when you try to explain it to someone else? Should be a great discussion!

From Goodreads: "One night at Trieste in September 1943 a seriously wounded soldier is found on the quay. The doctor, of a newly arrived German hospital ship, Pietri Friari gives the unconscious soldier medical assistance. His new patient has no documents or anything that can identifying him. When he regains consciousness he has lost his memory and cannot even remember what language he speaks. From a few things found on the man the doctor, who is originally from Finland, believes him to be a sailor and a fellow countryman, who somehow or other has ended up in Trieste. The doctor dedicates himself to teaching the man Finnish, beginning the reconstruction of the identity of Sampo Karjalainen, leading the missing man to return to Finland in search of his identity and his past."

name: If on a Winter's Night a Traveler by Italo Calvino
description:
Brad tells me we've hit just about 100 meetings and I can't figure out how to check so let's just pretend this is the 100th. To celebrate, we're going to loop back around and read Italo Calvino just like we did so many years ago. To boot this is a book that celebrates the reader, unlike so many books that only celebrate the writer.

From Goodreads: "Italo Calvino's novel is in one sense a comedy in which the two protagonists, the Reader and the Other Reader, ultimately end up married, having almost finished If on a Winter's Night a Traveler. In another, it is a tragedy, a reflection on the difficulties of writing and the solitary nature of reading... Calvino intersperses 10 different pastiches—stories of menace, spies, mystery, premonition—with explorations of how and why we choose to read, make meanings, and get our bearings or fail to."

We usually have a theme every month to discuss a specific type of reading, explore a specific card, or to share tarot spreads. We’ll update this description with more details about this month’s topic soon. Stay tuned!

Our meeting space is easily accessible by public transportation. Take the F, K, L, M or T lines and walk one block from Harvey Milk Plaza. Ride the 33 or 24 bus lines and get dropped off right by the entrance. Taxicabs are reliably available and abundant here.

Please bring your tarot deck (if you have one), a journal, and a pen to take notes.

Our meeting space does not have an electric kettle to make tea. If you’d like to consume a beverage, please bring your coffee or tea in a covered container.

name: MMQ San Francisco Drop-In Qigong Class: Friday 10:15am
description:
Qigong ("chee-gong") is mindful movement exercise designed to restore health, increase energy and open heart space to improve mood, function and overall well being! If you have yet to try it, please join us and experience the community, the benefits and fun! Class are great for beginners and experienced Qigongers alike. All levels of fitness, ability and experience are welcome to join. Each class will consist of qigong movements and exercises for self-healing and a guided meditation. Suzannah is an acupuncturist and medical qigong teacher and practitioner with clinics in both San Francisco and Berkeley, CA. She has been teaching Qigong since 2010 and is certified in both medical qigong therapy and as a qigong teacher by Suzanne Friedman, L.Ac., DMQ (China). Her mission is to support you in your health goals by sharing simple, easy to learn and powerful techniques for self-healing. Her goal is to create a qigong community in San Francisco that fosters vitality, health and tranquility in our everyday lives. Please contact her at [masked] with any questions or through her website:
www.SuzannahStason.com

Details about this class:

Drop-in available for $20 or a 6 class frequent qigonger pass is available for purchase for $100 at any class. Please bring cash or check. If you are limited income or a student, please contact me for sliding scale options. No one turned away for lack of funds. Payment is due before each class begins.

Wear comfortable, flowing clothing with layers as it might start off chilly and warm up as we get moving. Also, no outside shoes are allowed in the meditation room.
Meditation cushions, chairs and yoga mats are provided.

Schedule:

10:30-11:30am: Qigong warm-ups, Mindful Movement Qigong exercises with discussion of health effects, Daoist meditation to close

Looking forward to seeing & practicing with you soon!

name: Ganja Yoga - Restorative Hatha with Jess (Oakland)
description:
Quality instruction, relaxation-based yoga, mindful cannabis, and rad community, that's Ganja Yoga.

Founded in 2009 by author Dee Dussault.

REGISTER HERE:https://www.theganjayoga.com/tickets

The Oakland Ganja Yoga "kula" (community of the heart) - has been meeting twice a week for six months, and feature 'Dee Dussault's Ganja Yoga' - trained teacher, Jess Dugan, who teaches an all levels enhanced slow flow for relaxation and good vibes.

$15/class. Arrive 7:00-7:30 to enhance. Yoga goes 7:30-9, with optional time after class for tea if you'd like.

Flexibly-challenged stretchers to advanced yogis are welcome. This is a bring-your-own-cannabis class, and people always have plenty to share.

You must be age 21+ to attend. Bring ID.

FAQs
Do we need a MMJ card? Is cannabis provided?
Medical cards are not required since Prop 64, however, since it passed, we've had to become a "BYO" event." Adults are legally allowed to share, and there's always plenty to go around. We love our Papa & Barkley and Flow Kana for yoga!! :)

How much is mat rental?
Mats are free in Oakland.

Do you have any "karma yoga" programs to make Ganja Yoga more accessible?

Pay-what-you-can slots are set aside at every class for low income folk. Email [masked] to register.

Do I have to use cannabis at Ganja Yoga?
Yoga is great, altered or not. Sometimes students feel like enhance their practice with cannabis, cacao, essential oils, certain music (etc.), and other times, having a yoga practice without cannabis feels better. Its always up to you.

How much ganja should I consume for this practice?
First-timers to Ganja Yoga or yoga in general should consume less cannabis than they usually do, so the experience of yoga is enhanced. Everyone's relationship to cannabis is different.

Is it safe? What if I haven't done yoga before?
Ganja Yoga is about experiencing something beautiful and trippy and cool inside yourself. Most of the time our eyes are all closed, so its about relaxing in an introverted way, without caring what others are doing. Our flow is slow, mindful, and relaxation-based.

What are my transportation/parking options for getting to and from the event?
There is paid street parking, or its just a few minutes walk from BART. We recommend Lyft or BART.

“Ganja Yoga clears the mind and relaxes the body with the perfect blend of socialising, medicating and stretching. It is a must try for anyone in search of unique experiences but be aware that once you have been to the studio, you might get hooked.” - Robert

Study WebXR for Brain Computer Interfaces, with EEG, Oculus GO & Tensor Flow
description:
Hacknight: We are playing with things like WebXR, EEG, Oculus GO, Raspberry Pi Zero W, MySQL, Tensorflow, and Blockchain. Lets Study WebXR for Brain Computer Interfaces.

The latest updates: https://medium.com/silicon-valley-global-news/noisebridge-went-to-the-maker-faire-in-this-article-you-will-learn-about-ngalac-the-93f4857d3014

Ring Door Bell to get in. We are on the Mission St side of Noisebridge near the windows https://www.noisebridge.net/wiki/Getting_Here

Updates: We have successfully achieved connecting EEG to the Oculus Go via WebVR, we have also integrated FFT (Fast fourier transform) into the code, we are collecting time stamped user action data, and time stamped eeg data for the neural network portion of the project. We have replaced the original server written in Python with a new server written in GO.

How can we visualize biofeedback VR in 3D with WebXR? How can we collect user data to train Neural Networks?

You can optionally bring your own VR headset, laptop, and EEG device.

Watch the Neural Lace Podcast to get on track with the vision for this: Neural Lace Podcast Season 2 Episode 1 NeuroTechX and OpenEIT https://youtu.be/aexQwTpOwYc with Jean Rintoul

New! If you really want to be up to date please also watch the Neural Lace Podcast S2 E2 with Jules Urbach https://youtu.be/yMsaNsqzjFQ

Our objective is to merge Brain Machine Interfaces with WebXR, AR VR headsets, Machine Learning (Deep Learning Artificial Intelligence), Blockchain and more. To create new core medical technologies.

Our upcoming goals include
1. Update the WebVR visuals to make it more interesting, and to incorporate the new FFT data so that we are visualizing Alpha, Beta, Theta, Delta, Gamma waves. Also build a 3D Spectrogram in VR.

2. Figure out how to capture the time stamped user data (ie the user is looking at Cube3 at 9:05:47pm) and the time stamped EEG data from the VR headset, send it into a free cloud based database (like mysql), and use that to train a neural network (like tensorflow or ptorch or we could use baidu ez dl)

3. Broadcast our EEG server & html page to the open web so we are not using local hosts.

4. Migrate a version of the EEG server & html to the Raspberry Pi Zero W. and the Mac Mini

5. Secure the medical data (EEG) on the blockchain with Kara app by OasisLabs https://medium.com/oasislabs

Previous Progress: We made significant progress at the July 29th, 2018 meetup: We were able to cause voltages from the skin to move objects in WebVR. https://www.facebook.com/worksalt/videos/2332211350138832/

Be excellent to each other: Assume everyone else could be more knowledgeable about WebXR or 3D technology than you are. Never assume that women or other minorities or anyone else knows less than you about any topic! Assume you are among the best and brightest in the world, because the best and brightest in the world actually do come to the Noisebridge Hackerspace, NeurotechSF meetups, and SF VR meetups regularly.

Getting here: https://www.noisebridge.net/wiki/Getting_Here

Other links including the Github and our online groups: https://medium.com/@vrma/list-of-links-from-neurotech-sf-vr-on-8-31-2018-7a80cfd3901b

name: STORY TIME - Meet Lynn Fulton, Author of She Made a Monster […]
description:
You know the monster, but do you know who made him?

On the Bicentennial of the book Frankenstein by Mary Shelley, we are honored to have local author Lynn Fulton read her own spooky tale of the night Mary Shelley thought up her infamous Monster. It's a stormy night two hundred years ago, and young Mary is surrounded by her fellow writer friends: All around her she felt the power of words, and she hoped that someday she too would write something important. Something that would hit the world like a bolt of lightning splitting the night sky. But for now, she only wanted to write a ghost story.

Kirkus Review says, An elegant picture book that will signal to young readers that there is more to the story than the familiar green-skinned monster.

Are you not an iOS Developer, but interested in to get started? No worries, please feel free to join us, and we can guide you to the fun iOS Development world!

DESCRIPTION
Join Marissa Johnson, and Kyle MacLaren from KPMG for a discussion on the Startup Success Guide to Growth

Founders face considerable challenges as they work to bring new ideas to the marketplace while taking incremental leadership responsibilities. Raising capital, finding talent, acquiring customers, complying with regulatory requirements, and other management initiatives take time and are important to maximize business success. Thanks to the lean start-up process and technology advances, entrepreneurs are scaling companies to sizeable revenues with smaller teams and less cash than just a few years ago. The cycle of innovation is speeding up, and talented entrepreneurs are ready to take over and invent the next disruptive technologies.

Our guests Marissa and Kyle will share highlights from the operational, financial, tax and accounting best practices they have seen through their experience. This conversation will give you the tools to grow your company, don't miss out!

This session is for:

Launch (product/service being used by customers)

Growth (scaling customers, products/services and markets)

Hyper Growth (growing your team and expertise at the same time as products/services and customers)

11:00AM – 11:30AM – Networking

name: Work Jam + Networking
description:
Working alone is no fun…

Solution? Work Jam! Get things done and meet like-minded people while working together.

Join a group of no more than 6 people in the above-mentioned location, get out your laptop/notebook, declare your goals to the group and start working!

Our 5-minute breaks between 25-minute work sessions will also allow you to know the other participants.

Want to make it even more interesting?
Every time a Work Jam happens in one of our 90+ groups around the world, our Telegram work jam channel will also magically be active, so you can also feed your goals for each session there: https://t.me/workjams

The group is limited to max. 6 participants, so if you can't make it, please cancel to allow someone else to join.

If you arrive first, please write a comment below about where you're sitting and how to identify you (e.g. shirt color). If you don't see a comment, you are the first person, so please post one and join our Telegram channel in the meantime so you don't feel alone https://t.me/workjams

Why Work Jams?
Working together is proved to boost productivity. It will create the accountability as you will declare your goals and results for each session. Also, meeting new people while working together will connect you to potential team members, clients and friends. It's a powerful mix of focused work with networking short breaks.

What will happen?
We'll start with introductions and networking (first 10 min). Then we'll do 3 Pomodoro sessions of 25 minutes each, with 5 minute breaks between each pomodoro work session. If you like it you may actually stay and continue working even longer, why not?

How we'll work
We'll follow "Pomodoro Technique", which is a popular time management and productivity method of 25 minutes of work and 5 minutes break. If your group is big enough, you can just create a pomodoro timer at https://www.marinaratimer.com/ and start it when everyone is ready. Before you do, it is optional for everyone to declare their goal for the session. If you rather stick with our "global timer", join us at https://t.me/workjams and receive the link to the timer there.

name: Change Beliefs and Create
description: PRACTICED: Are you a believer in the Law of Attraction? Do you believe that what you focus on and think about contributes to the creation of your reality? Are you eager to meet like-minded people who share your philosophy? Then we want to meet you! Come share your stories of deliberate creation or listen to others and be inspired NOVICES: Are you just wrapping your mind around the concept of Law of Attraction? How is it that you manifest what you desire? How do you live in joy the majority of the time? If you are seeking answers to these kinds of questions, then we want to meet you. Come share your passion and expand you mind LOGISTICS: This is an informal gathering in a quiet public space (e.g. coffee shop, cafe, hotel, courtyard). When we meet in an establishment, it is customary to be a responsible consumer and we ask that you support the business through a reasonable purchase (i.e. coffee, tea, beer, wine, light meal, etc.). For alternate location ideas, please suggest, so that this group can expand to different communities VIRTUAL: No Virtual will be offered in this meet up. AGENDA: I have added the Agenda below from the group consciousness • Please arrive in advance to make any food and beverage purchases (recommended but not required). In addition, the facilitator will initiate the Virtual Meeting to address connections logistics 15 minutes prior to meeting start time 1) NEW MEMBER: The meeting will begin with any new member introductions and everyone will have an opportunity to share how they discovered the Law of Attraction for themselves 2) HAVE CREATED: Following introductions (and if no new members are present, this is the beginning), returning members will have an opportunity to share how they have applied the principles of Law of Attraction since their most recent attended meeting 3) TOOLS: The meeting will continue with round table discussions centered in Creation through Law of Attraction and redirection may be implemented to focus on tools (e.g. re-writing limited beliefs, success stories, and sharing intentions) 4) WILL CREATE: Approximately 15 minutes prior to close, the meeting will wrap up, offering each member an opportunity to share their intentions and how they will apply the principles of Law of Attraction routinely • Members are welcome to remain and socialize at the end of the discussion • Please note the agenda is necessary to communicate expectations, however the timeline is loose to allow for organic discussions

name: #39 - IOT Designers: Andrea Trasatti meet Leandro Agró
description:
Program

6:30-7:00 - Networking
7:00-7:50 - Leandro and Andrea in conversation
7:50-8:00 - Q&A and Discussion

Leandro Agró (Design Group Italia) in conversation with Andrea Trasatti (Samsung-ArtiK)

Everyday Objects are a testimony of human habits and culture. They can help us to better understand the society in which we live in. Connected Objects - aka Internet of Things - will create memories of us. Better than any artifact ever built before.

This talk will offer a point of view that starts from an Italian design perspective and it will take us to imagine our near future. Leandro Agro -Design Group Italia and author of the books "IoT Designer" and "Internet of Humans", meets Andrea Trasatti (Senior Product Manager at Samsung-ArtiK). Our two speakers will discuss what it means to be a “technology designer” today and what is the internet of things. Together we will dig deeper, exploring the meaning of “cultural acceptability”, and how the “asymmetric aging of physical objects and software” works. Among other topics, we will talk about how to find a balance between local-autonomy of objects and remote-intelligences located into the clouds, and how connected objects are changing organizations that are designing and producing them.

If you are an IoT user, designer, or programmer, this presentation will give you a new and fresh perspective on this new technology.

Leandro Agró
Leandro is an awarded IxD/UX Director, IoT pioneer, patents contributor with 20+ years of design and team leadership. He served brands like Warner Bros, Unicef, Orange, Generali, Jansenn, Symantech, Eni, 3M, PepsiCo collecting –during the path- 2 WebAwards, 2 TechGarage prize, 2 ADI index mentions and other accomplishment including an early award at the Apple Design Project.

Leandro is also founder and co-author of Frontiers of Interactions a leading Interaction design Conference; Frontiers is the place where the design and technology guru from all over the planet meets together. Past speaker list includes the inventor of TED conference Richard Saul Wurman, the founder of Activision David Crane, the godfather of the Internet of Things Bruce Sterling, the theorist of the New Economy Kevin Kelly, the author of the Whole Earth Catalog Stewart Brand and many others top designers from Google, Yahoo, Jawbone, Twitter, etc.

He is also shareholder at SrLabs (world class technology in the Eye Tracking field), JoinPad (leader in the augmented reality technology, including high professional AR Glasses) and TOK.tv (absolutely the best Sport dedicated social platform, serving more than 20MM users and 3 of the top 4 soccer club worldwide).

Leandro is the author of "Internet of Humans" (Egea) and I contributed to seven other books.
As speaker he talked at: Disruptive Week (2015), Richmond IT Director Forum (2013), TED MED live (2012), TEDx (2011), CSR4 Research Center (2010), World Usability Day (2009), UXCON (2009, 2011), Internet Evolution (2009), Birds of a Feather at ETech (2008), World Business Forum (2007), BayCHI (2007).

During his professional life, several magazines, newspapers and TV shows mentioned my projects or interviewed me. This list includes: WIRED, Mashable, Reuters, New York Times, CNN, Creative Communication, Glamour and all main Italian newspaper and TV.

Andrea Trasatti
Andrea Trasatti has been at the forefront of technology for almost 20 years working on Internet access services first, then SMS and WAP (the predecessor of the mobile Web). Andrea was among the other things an active promoter of bringing Web content to mobile phones working for Nokia and with the W3C defining the standards for content and browsers. More recently Andrea has moved to Digital Health and IoT. At Samsung Andrea is responsible for developer relations and partner management, building an ecosystem of products and services for IoT

name: The Shanti Gentle All-Bodies Yoga Sessions w/Ian Waisler
description:
The Shanti Gentle All-Bodies Yoga Sessions  

It happens on Tuesdays –

The Sessions will start at 4:00 PM and ends at 5:30 PM. Please get there by 3:45 PM - 3:50 PM to be let in.

It will be hosted by Ian Waisler. The sessions may include chanting, stretching, both to energize and relax you.

This group is ideal for anyone with an HIV, cancer or other health challenging diagnosis

This is a gentle all-bodies yoga with unfettered instruction - so, expect some individual attention in the group setting. This individualized attention will help folks move as is natural for their body abilities.

EASEFUL postures, deep relaxation and breathing practices that are suitable for EVERYONE at ANY LEVEL.

ACCESSIBLE teachings nad simple techniques designed to reduce stress and enhance overall health and well-being.

CONNECT with a community determined to survive and throve despite their health diagnosis

Ian is an amazing and intuitive instructor.

Derrick Mapp at[masked] or [masked]

name: Coffee and learning design
description: Join us to discuss ideas for designing engaging, effective learning programs and activities!

name: Instructional Design Workshop
description:
Cost: $295 to $395, depending upon ATD membership status.

Please click here for more details and to register on the ATD Golden Gate chapter website (http://www.tdgoldengate.org/event-2850325).

(Go to: http://www.tdgoldengate.org/event-2850325 if the above link does not work for you.)

In this two-day workshop you will design compelling and effective training, use accelerated learning techniques and learn the 5 key instructional steps to get participant involvement and better results.

During the workshop, you will:

1. Write an instructional design within the first two hours. That’s accelerated!
2. Experience 10 different ways to change boring instruction and lectures into interactive exercises.
3. Get one-on-one coaching on your instructional design. Enjoy designing training that's fun.

Facilitator: Kris Schaeffer, CPLP, has 40 years of experience in human resource development. Kris’s professional work has focused on the analysis and design of customized training. Her instructional designs for customer service, sales, and safety training have been adopted by entire industries such as the cable + phone, direct store delivery (soft drinks, beer, snacks), and food manufacturing. Kris teaches subject experts how to design training so they can pass along their knowledge and skills so others can master them.

name: NORTH BAY: Spotlight on Sutter Health: training in the healthcare industry
description:
Cost: Free to $20, depending upon ATD membership status.

Please click here for more details and to register on the ATD Golden Gate chapter website. (http://www.tdgoldengate.org/event-3070596)

(If the above link does not work for you, please go to: http://www.tdgoldengate.org/event-3070596)

Take an inside look at training in the healthcare industry. Get an overview of the different types of audiences within a healthcare organization and how training is applied to these audiences. Learn about the unique relationship between training and information services and see how that impacts technology training. Learn how different training modalities (ILT, VT, One on One, and E-learning) are applied within the Sutter Health system.

name: ASL Coffee Meetup (all welcome) before DNO
description:
ASL Coffee before DNO
(earlier under 21 & all ASL level Students meet at coffee shop; Be respectful and use your hands or bring pad of paper)

6:30pm ASL Coffee Meetup
at Peets Coffee, 2257 Market Street, SF Castro
for all levels of students welcome at ASL Coffee. (DNO restrictions below)

DNO
for Deaf, hard of hearing and ASL Allies
8pm-12:00amish
over 21 bar with restaurant
(not recommended for basic hearing signers below ASL level 3-see DNO rules below)

DNO is usually at 'Lookout' bar & pizza place in 'Video Lounge'

in Castro[masked]th X Market BART to MUNI easy..

COST: Door charge free if you give ‘illy’! But, do buy at least one drink even if it is Coke.

TRAVEL: from any downtown BART take MUNI 'F' line or any underground K, L, M and then walk 2 blocks.

From National DNO: 'Our goal is to provide you with good times, good folks, and good cheer in good places. To do that we organize Deaf Night Out.'

DNO is a regular event 1st Saturdays in SF (except when other community event) for the Deaf & signing communities. Deaf adults, interpreters, signing students (level 3 and above)...

We work with network of DNO-Bay Area, DNO-South Bay, DNO-East Bay event hosts that work together to meet a common standard and provide a setting where we can all be welcomed.

So check your attitude at the door, let your hair down and your hands fly. Young and old; tall and short; fat and thin; come one, come all and celebrate the richness and diversity of your fabulous community!

https://www.facebook.com/groups/dnobayarea/

NEW ASL STUDENTS PLEASE READ...

ASL Coffee and DNO are separate events. Most Deaf community members, ASL teachers and DNO itself refer students lower than ASL level 3 to go to ASL Coffee. But, Not DNO. Please offer your seat or space to Deaf or hard of hearing people. 'Make room at the table' or offer your seat.

*Deaf Night Out & ASL Epic is a space reserved for ASL ONLY. It is reserved for Deaf, Deaf Blind, and hard of hearing. We ask you to be respectful of the space we desperately need."

PLEASE COME. BUT, RESPECT OUR CULTURAL RULES...

We live in a hearing world 24/7 and we need a space where we can just be ourselves. With this in mind, no voicing unless by interpreter. Absolutely NO VOICING during chat or social times. ASL Allies are welcome but, if you come to social do not expect people to slow down their signing. Asking for clarification is ok.But, if you still don't understand after continued clarification then sit back and absorb and don't interrupt conversations. ASL Allies please continue to help us build a safe and fun space (e.g.: hearing ASL students, hearing partners or hearing interpreters)! Thank you for your understanding and support!*

#SignsInMyRoots #SanFranciscoArt #DeafTalent #DeafHeart #DeafDance #DeafCommunity #ASL #SignLanguage#Deaf #aslepic #dno #dnosf #sfdno #deafnightout #deafnightoutsf #deafnightoutsanfrancisco #deafshow #aslshow #hardofhearing #deafshow

name: Fundraising event for Jean Parker Elem. at SOMA Street Eats (1 - 4pm)
description:
Jean Parker Elementary School is having their annual Asian Street Market fundraiser at SoMa StrEat Food Park. Funds raised will help support the school’s P.E. and dance programs. The event will feature Asian food trucks and live entertainment.

Jean Parker Elementary School's goal is to educate the whole child through our supportive and nurturing learning environment. The Parent Teacher Organization of the school exists to facilitate communication between parents and staff and to raise money for enrichment programs and school needs insufficiently funded by local, state and federal sources.

What we'll be doing:

- Selling tickets and check in ticket holders
- Acting as door staff, ensuring that outside food and beverage does not enter the venue as well as checking for hand stamps/wristbands
- Door staff for indoor food demo area
- Bus tables and act as an extra set of eyes, spotting and reporting safety hazards, restrooms in need of maintenance, full trash cans, etc.

The volunteer functions are primarily outdoors. Dress for comfort and in layers for SF weather. Sunglasses and hats are suggested for comfort. Belongings may be left in the venue’s office, but keep valuables with you/the venue and school are not responsible for any lost items.

Getting here:
The meeting place is the front entrance of SoMa StrEat Food Park at[masked]th Street across the street from Costco. There are limited free street parking on the surrounding streets. Paid parking options nearby include SOMA Hub Garage[masked]th Street ($5 for 2 hours; $5 each additional hour), and 24 Florida St., which is $6 for all day parking. Some buses that run near the venue include the MUNI 9, 12, and 47.

https://californiaparking.com/pay-by-phone.shtml.

name: Serve Lunch at Downtown Senior Center with Project Open Hand - 3 Volunteers
description:
Project Open Hand is a partnership of volunteers, donors, and staff working to provide vital nourishment to people living with HIV/AIDS, seniors, and homebound individuals living with serious illness. They serve over 8,000 clients with a multitude of services that include meal delivery and pick up, weekly bags of groceries and hot lunches at senior sites.

Volunteer Duties and Shift Lengths:

Project Open Hand has 15 Community Nutrition Program (CNP) sites, plus one Adults with Disabilities (AWD) site, located across San Francisco. Volunteers at our meal sites help us create a warm, welcoming atmosphere for our senior and AWD clients. Specific duties during a volunteer shift may include registering clients for lunch, setting up the dining room, pre-meal prep, plating food, serving food and helping with clean-up after the meal. The volunteer shift lengths vary from location to location and range from 2 to 3.5 hours. Depending on the size of the CNP or AWD site, we typically take between 1 and 5 volunteers for a single volunteer shift.

Food Safety:

It is extremely important to maintain a high standard of cleanliness when we handle food.

Dress appropriately in close-toed shoes, shirts with sleeves (no tank tops), pants that cover the full leg, and that you don't mind getting dirty.

Suit up! Take an apron, hairnet, and gloves near the prep sink.

Wash your hands with soap and warm water and replace your gloves every time you use the restroom, shake someone's hand, or switch from food preparation to cleaning.

If you are sick or not feeling well, STAY HOME!

Before arriving, please direct your browser to the release form which will also notify POH of your attendance:

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1sDnqC-4azTSs4g2EDcy4tu7e5Lau0ik7I71zJGv-cBY/edit?usp=sharing

How to get to the senior center:

The building is on the corner of O'Farrell and Jones. It's best to take public transit to the Powell Street Station and walk to the center.

description:
